title: chinas ministry agriculture declares dogs pets not eating landmark
story: China has moved towards a full ban on eating dogs by stating they should not be regarded as livestock for human consumption.In a move that will be welcomed by animal welfare campaigners the country’s Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs has revised a list of livestock animals which can be traded for meat.China temporarily restricted wildlife trading and consumption in February, in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak thought to have originated in ‘wet’ markets where live animals are sold alongside slaughtered meat.The Ministry of Agriculture explicitly signalled a move towards a permanent ban on the sale of dog meat in a draft document published on Wednesday and open to public consultation until May 8.With the progress of human civilisation and the public's concern and preference for animal protection, dogs have changed from traditional domestic animals to companion animals, the document stated.Dogs are generally not regarded as livestock and poultry around the world, and China should also not manage them as livestock and poultry.Although dogs and cats were not on the official livestock list in the past, it is the first time the government has commented on dogs.The move comes ahead of the Yulin Dog Meat Festival held in the city of Yulin, Guangxi, during the summer solstice, at which festival goers eat dog meat and lychees.Thousands of dogs are reportedly consumed during the 10-day festival, which began in 2009, and it has been heavily criticised both in China and abroad.Festival organisers claim that the dogs are killed humanely, but opponents say the animals are treated cruelly, with graphic videos showing dogs being boiled, skinned, and blow torched alive,Animal rights campaigners have welcomed the move by the Chinese authorities.This draft proposal could signal a game-changer moment for animal protection in China, said Wendy Higgins, spokeswoman for Humane Society International.The proposed restrictions come as the ‘wet’ markets begin to reopen in Wuhan, where the new strain of coronavirus which has engulfed the globe first surfaced. However, the ban on slaughtering and selling live animals remains in place.Scientists and Chinese officials believe the deadly virus  jumped to humans from wild animals, via creatures such as bats.Close contact with wild animals at the markets, which had been closed since January, has been widely blamed for the outbreak.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus entered new york europe not asia researchers find
story: One study has found an early case of the virus in the city was in all likelihood indirectly transmitted by an inidual who brought it across from Britain.But while President Donald Trump barred foreign nations at the end of January from entering the US if they had been in China, it was not until mid-March that similar restrictions were placed on travellers from most European countries.Researchers suggest that by this point travellers had already been returning to New York with coronavirus from countries such as Italy.They found that the Long Island patient’s viral genome correlated with that of a strain circulating in Britain. That suggested the patient had contact with someone who had brought the virus over from the UK.Scientists at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital have written a study also indicating that coronavirus began to circulate in the New York area by mid-February, weeks before the first confirmed case, and that the travelers who brought in the virus did not arrive from Asia.Harm van Bakel, a geneticist at Icahn who co-wrote the study, which is awaiting peer review, told The New York Times: “The majority is clearly European.” Both teams examined genomes from coronaviruses taken from New Yorkers from mid-March.Their research appears to suggest that the previously hidden spread of the virus might have been detected earlier if more testing had been in place.China announced at the end of December that doctors in Wuhan were treating dozens of cases of a new respiratory illness.A few countries, such as Singapore, launched an aggressive testing program to identify the arrival of the virus and trace its spread through the population.But the US initially limited testing only to people who had come from China in the two weeks before January 31 and displayed symptoms of Covid-19.Dr Heguy said: “It was a disaster that we didn’t do testing. People were just oblivious.”One passenger, Pam Mundus, who returned home on a direct flight from Rome to JFK on March 1, said at the time that no one questioned her about her visit to Italy, or whether she might have been exposed to the virus. Early findings suggest that the virus was in New York well before a woman in her 30s from Manhattan became the city’s first official patient on March 1.Dr Viviana Simon, of the team, said in a statement that the results indicate that the coronavirus “came to New York City and environs predominantly via untracked transmission between the United States and Europe, with only limited introduction from China, where the virus originated.”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus next 100 days future uk economy health
story: On new year's eve last year the first case of Covid-19 was reported to the WHO. As of today, Thursday 9 April 2020, we are one hundred days in to living with the virus.We asked our expert journalists to look ahead and forecast what the next 100 days will hold. What is the outlook for their sector? Which key questions must be answered? And what will their world look like 100 days from now, on Saturday 18 July? The areas covered are as follows: The UK, the world, science, politics, the NHS, lockdown and social distancing, the economy, small and medium businesses, personal finance, property, sport, the arts, environment, education, mental health, physical health, travel and Brexit.These are their responses.If the first 100 days of this pandemic have been characterised by collective shock, denial and now frustration, we should expect the next three months to be marked by our adaptability. It’s what pychologists call the Kübler-Ross model, or the “five stages of grief”, and is a useful way of thinking about what the coronavirus holds for us over the weeks and months ahead. The model is usually shown as a bowl-shaped curve with the “shock” on the high left, a steep descent into depression and then a slow but steady rise to a new normal.The upward slope of the curve may have been what The Queen had in mind when she told the nation on Sunday: While we have faced challenges before, this one is different. We join with all nations across the globe in a common endeavour, using the great advances of science and our instinctive compassion to heal. We will succeed – and that success will belong to every one of us”.The shock of the past 100 days has been brutal, but the green shoots of recovery are becoming evident. The way we came together to demand a lockdown in order to protect the most vulnerable among us is testament not just to our humanity but our good sense. Darwinian forces may have shaped us but we see ourselves as a society not a herd. You see it too in the millions of small chores and errands people all over the country are running for those less able than themselves.Scientists from all disciplines have also grown in stature and confidence. They are displacing ideology with evidence and knee jerk reaction with reasoned decision making. They are also embracing cross-border cooperation and transparency like never before. One of the first papers providing hard evidence that infection with the coronavirus creates protective antibodies in our blood was published yesterday by a team of Chinese scientists and shared instantly around the world. In the same vein, the once secretive scientific committees advising ministers in Britain have taken to publishing, not just the abbreviated minutes of their meetings, but the substance too in order that others can constantly test and critique their decision making.Even the public are becoming involved. Perhaps the best view we have of the spread of the coronavirus in Britain is provided by data from the Covid Symptom Tracker app, used by over two million ordinary Brits. The latest figures estimate that 1.4 million people in the UK aged 20-69 have symptomatic Covid-19, a fall from 1.9 million on the 1 April.While scientists are working round the clock on treatments and vaccines, thousands of other experts are collaborating on the economics and logistics of getting our factories, schools and high streets up and running again.Don’t expect lockdown to end within the next 100 days but we will almost certainly know the shape of it by then.Life is unlikely to fully return to normal until a vaccine or treatment is found but with good planning and direction from the top, it should be possible for large parts of society to be at least partially freed-up without the virus spiking dangerously again and overwhelming the NHS..If there is a risk in front of us, and there surely is, it comes less from the virus itself but the profound economic and political shock which the world will experience in its wake. We know from history that such shocks like this can spark conflict and already China and the US are squaring up to each other, stoking palpable fear and tensions.Covid-19 has exposed the world’s frailties and its strengths: we humans have a long established habit of messing up before dusting ourselves down and starting over again. Be in no doubt, we will get back on our feet. The only real variable is how many people will die unnecessarily in the process.There are really only three kinds of country in the world today: those slowly waking from the coronavirus nightmare those in the middle of it and those who are about to be hit.All face the same brutal dilemma: how to balance human lives and public health with economic sustainability.Over the next few weeks each will see their latent weaknesses, and perhaps strengths, exposed in unforgiving light. And the outcomes will vary dramatically according to national wealth.China, South Korea, and Japan, the advanced economies which suffered the first wave of the coronavirus crisis, will try to ease their city lockdowns without allowing a resurgence of the virus.But early signs are that it will be a tricky and long-drawn out process. Tellingly China has still not rescheduled the annual meeting of the National People's Congress, which was postponed in March, suggesting Beijing is not quite confident that progress is irreversible.Meanwhile, developed countries in Europe and North America where the epidemic has yet to peak will remain focussed on saving lives. Lockdowns may be extended into the early summer, and tensions over the economic, social, and political consequences will rise.The mounting death rate in the United States in particular poses an immense challenge to president Donald Trump in the run-up to November's presidential election, and could challenge orthodoxies around healthcare.Everywhere, the global economic slowdown will have knock-on effects with as yet impossible to predict consequences.The Kremlin's spokesman warned Russians last weekend to be braced for a perfect storm economic crisis lasting up to two years.  But alarmingly, a third wave hitting the developing world is only now taking off.With neither the healthcare capacity to handle multiple cases nor the economic reserves to survive the shutdowns that saved lives in Europe and East Asia, the outbreaks are likely to last longer and claim many more lives.Aid agencies are especially worried about conflict zones like Libya, where an outbreak of the virus has failed to slow the fighting, and refugee camps, where cramped conditions and rudimentary sanitation mean thousands of people will likely die if the virus takes hold.  In the world's largest refugee camps in Cox's Bazaar, Bangladesh, there is not a single venilator for more than 800,000 Rohingya refugees who fled a genocide in Myanmar in 2017. Médicines sans Frontier have described the camps, which are overcrowded and unsanitary as a ticking time bomb.The first 100 days of the coronavirus have brought the economy to a ‘hard stop’ the likes of which has never been seen before.Preventative action to stop the spread of the pandemic has forced the shutdown of swathes of British and global productive capacity.The next 100 days begins with a reckoning in the jobs market. Economists expect GDP to fall by as much as 20 per cent by the end of April.JP Morgan estimates such a fall would be expected to push up unemployment from below 4 per cent at the start of the year to as much as 13 per cent - far worse than the financial crisis or the recessions of the 1980s and 1990s.Almost 1m have signed up for benefits already. Typically that would cause serious scarring as some of the unemployed lose touch with the world of work for years, finding it hard to get a job and seeing their skills lose value as they are not kept up to date with modern employment.If the furlough schemes and business support efforts work the unemployment rate could be limited to around 7 per cent, staving off the worst social and economic effects of the crunch.The next key factor is the length of the shutdown. If restrictions begin to be eased in May, a rapid bounceback seems possible. Retail and hospitality can begin to reopen, bit by bit.Domestic travel can recommence. Workers on furlough or working from home can get back to normal work. Government efforts to ‘bridge’ this period with grants, loans and wage payments will have largely succeeded in keeping the economy from collapse.“We expect the economy to rebound quite swiftly, should quarantine measures be lifted sometime before the third quarter,” says economist Sanjay Raja at Deutsche Bank.This would not restore the economy to its previous peak instantly. International travel and large-scale events will take longer to return to normal. Lost education, training and investment could also take time to be recovered.Behaviours could change, too. Businesses and households may build up more savings to keep themselves safe from any ‘second wave’ or other future lockdown. That is the good scenario.But if the shutdown carries on into June or even to the end of the next 100 days, the economy could look very different.More businesses and jobs will have been lost for good. Those who are still standing risk lower incomes or higher debts. Businesses will be less willing to fund new investment in a weaker economy, and workers risk losing their skills after a prolonged period of forced rest.In that case, a long depression could lie ahead.In early January the World Health Organization issued an alert warning that a “pneumonia of unknown cause” had been identified in Wuhan, China. Just a few days later the mystery illness was confirmed to be a novel coronavirus and within a week Chinese scientists had published its full genetic sequence. Since then, experts across the globe have been scrambling to uncover the virus’ secrets. While miracles will not happen overnight, never before have scientists been so united in a common pursuit – and already a remarkable amount of progress has been made. “There is this spirit of collaboration,” Nick Cammack, therapeutics accelerator lead at the Wellcome Trust, told The . “Science is the exit strategy.” Looking forward, there are three key areas that experts are honing in on. The first is to answer the outstanding unknowns: How many of us have already had the virus? How common are asymptomatic carriers? And how much immunity, if any, do we acquire after surviving an infection?Widespread antibody testing will unlock many of these answers, as accurate assays will be able to detect prior infections and identify whether we are approaching widespread immunity. Scientists at the UK’s high tech, high security facility at Porton Down near Salisbury are among those who have already started this work – expect answers in the near future. Identifying effective treatments is another essential area of focus. While experts have started to track down completely new compounds that could be used to attack the coronavirus in the future, the most promising option right now is to repurpose existing drugs.Antimalarial treatments first tested during the Second World War (chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine), a combination drug used to treat HIV patients (ritonavir and lopinavir) and an antiviral first developed to treat Ebola (remdesivir) have all been pitted as potential cures, alongside convalescent plasma therapy and anti-inflammatories.While hundreds of clinical trials have started during the pandemic, it is the “megatrials” launched by the WHO, University of Oxford and French firm Inserm that will offer the most conclusive results as they have the largest sample sizes. Initial results for some of the potential therapies could start to emerge within a month. The final, and perhaps most critical, tool is a vaccine. About 35 companies and academic institutes are racing to create an inoculation and four candidates have already been tested in animals – but experts have warned it will be at least a year, if not 18 months, until a safe vaccine is ready for widespread use. Efforts are under way to speed this process up. Bill Gates announced this week that he would build factories to manufacture the seven most promising vaccines – even though this would “waste” billions of dollars, as the Gates Foundation would only ever mass produce two candidates. It’s a sign, if you needed one, of just how seriously the international community is taking the coronavirus threat. “Science is the exit strategy” might be a savvy soundbite, but it’s also true. The NHS has worked at full throttle to plan for the peak of the coronavirus outbreak, creating 10,000 extra intensive care beds at NHS Nightingale Hospitals and asking tens of thousands of retired medics and students to join the fight. Consultant surgeons have retrained as ICU nurses, as operating theatres and labour wards have been converted into Covid-19 wards.  When the peak comes in the next 10 to 20 days, with London and the West Midlands expected to come first, we will see if the preparations were sufficient.Staffing will be a major pinch point. A workforce deficit of 100,000 before the crisis will be compounded by medics going off sick - up to 25 per cent of staff are already self-isolating, according to the highest estimates. Increased testing will help, but medics will need to adapt.Nurses in ICU, who normally look after one patient at a time, could be asked to monitor half a dozen at once, while doctors will improvise with anaesthetic machines when ventilators are all in use and move patients around the hospital to maintain oxygen pressure. After insufficient amounts of PPE equipment were delivered in the early days of the crisis, fixes to the supply chain should hold up.As hospitals reach capacity, ambulances will be re-routed to NHS Nightingale Hospitals. NHS Providers has early confidence that hospitals won’t become overwhelmed, as they were in Italy, but is concerned about the effect on community services, such as GPs and social care. Frontline charities, such as St John's Ambulance, will need to draw on new funding from the Government in order to support the NHS.Coronavirus deaths will be commonplace, and medics will find themselves standing in for loved ones. They will facilitate video calls with family members, play comforting music, and hold patients' hands as they take their last breath. Medics will also die. There could also be a rise in non-corona deaths, as patients avoid going to A&ampE and miss out on treatment.After the peak hospital admissions will plateau, but it will take weeks for the effect to be seen on wards as critical patients recover. Lockdown measures will help avoid a second peak, while contact tracing and immunity testing will become key.“People are putting on brave faces when in fact they are crying inside,” one ICU doctor tells me. NHS staff will rely upon a new NHS mental health helpline and ‘wobble rooms’ to ease the burden, but some will suffer from PTSD. Without a doubt, though, they will continue to work as hard as they can.As Dr Qian Xu, an A&ampE doctor, says, “We are all scared, just like everyone else, but we have a professional duty to fight this war.The lockdown has obviously pushed us further apart. We can't see loved ones we can't go to work the public sphere, famously described by Jurgen Habermas as the place where ideas and experiences are freely exchanged, is gone. Even if we do go for a walk, we have to keep two metres apart, and our faces are hidden behind masks. This is deeply ironic given how much time Europe spent debating whether or not women should wear the Burqa.On the other hand, this is the closest we've come to a collective experience in years. We are suddenly watching the same news and digesting the same information. We're probably talking to each other more than ever over phone and internet, and hundreds of thousands have volunteered to help the NHS. There is evident national pride at the construction of NHS Nightingale, the largest critical unit in the world, in just nine days.Criticism of politicians and suspicion that we might be getting this wrong, is balanced by the feeling that we're all in this together, even if all we can do is shout hello from a safe distance.But these are early days. Lockdown Britain is going to have to process two traumas. First, death. People die all the time, but rarely in one go and with the same condition, and never with this degree of media attention. Given the scale of mortality it's likely that almost every family will be touched by it but, due to the lockdown, we'll be denied many of the usual rites and companionship that we rely upon to cope with grief.Second, we are going to have to confront the trauma of prolonged boredom, unemployment and loneliness. There's been growing awareness in recent years of the link between mental and physical health, that if you are depressed or unstimulated, physical problems follow. Well, now we are engaged in a mass experiment in enforced isolation or, just as difficult, being stuck with the same person for a long period of time. One suspects that as frustrations increase, so will tensions between the generations.The phrase things will never be the same again is almost as over-familiar as stay at home - but it's not necessarily true.Some things will go straight back to normal when the lockdown ends because we miss them and we want them back: the pubs will be jam-packed and flights will sell out. But the Coronavirus could always return for another season, or some other disease, so we are likely to be left feeling very vulnerable for a long time.Sport’s shutdown narrowly allowed the real Cheltenham Gold Cup and has just given us the Virtual Grand National. In between, the industry’s business model has been exposed as over-reliant on TV deals and reckless with its salaries for players.Pent-up longing will bring fans swarming back into stadiums. Britain’s love for sport was always deep but now we will see new heights of appreciation. But football, in particular, has stretched the public’s loyalty, with billionaire-owned Premier League clubs using the government’s furlough system to transfer staff wage costs to taxpayers. The cries of poverty emanating from many clubs and sports organisations have invited scrutiny around how they are run and where all the money goes.With Euro 2020, the Olympics, Wimbledon and The Open lost or postponed, the English sporting summer, a mainstay of our culture, has been wiped out. Another hundred days from now, in mid-July, cricket’s new smash-ball form, The Hundred, teeters as August and September become the best hopes for a resumption. The Hundred was meant to be cricket’s new goldmine but may not be seen until 2021.Football’s quandary is the most pressing. It hopes to complete the 2019-20 season before the next one can commence in August - or later - in large part to avoid paying rebates to broadcasters for uncompleted fixtures. Last season in the Premier League, Liverpool amassed 97 points but still fell short of the title, which they have not won for 30 years. This time they are 25 points clear with nine games left but are at the mercy of a microbe.Industry watchers predict a “bloodbath” as budgets are slashed and jobs cut. Sport’s complacent belief that the show would always go on has unravelled in the face of a pandemic - and even superstars have lost their omnipotence. Many will be feeling physically and mentally frazzled and will need time to regain their form.A country in need of life-affirming spectacles is desperate to see them back from their lockdowns. Yet the financial damage will take many years to correct. A return to the old ways of funnelling vast revenues to the performers and their agents with no structural underpinnings would show that lessons had not been learned.Hopes remain for live sport in July, or perhaps more realistically, August, but mass gatherings will be the last of the prohibitions eased by the government, so we may see sport proceed at first with turnstiles locked.One hundred days ago, Boris Johnson and the Conservative Party were still basking in the glory of an unexpectedly large election triumph. That victory came from a transformation of the party. A new Tory coalition was forged from disillusioned Labour voters in the Midlands, the North and Wales through a politics that was more Left-wing when it came to splashing the cash, but more Right-wing on key social issues such as immigration.Nowhere was the transformation more clear than at the new Chancellor, Rishi Sunak’s Budget, where he opened the spending taps for tens of billions on roads, rail and broadband.Yet that Budget also marked a turning point. Mr Sunak announced £60 billion of spending to battle the economic fallout of the Coronavirus pandemic. Within days he was announcing billions of pounds more. And more again a few days after that. By then, all other priorities were on hold.As for the next 100 days, several major questions hang over the Government. The most obvious and immediate is how and when to lift the lockdown. Ministers and their scientific advisers are juggling a number of factors. They know that collapsed businesses and raging unemployment could lead to health problems just as damaging as the epidemic itself. But move too soon, overwhelm the NHS and see death rates from any and all illnesses and accidents spike, and the economy would be in dire straits anyway.When it ends, the epidemic will have complicated significantly the long-term goals of the Tory Party. The pandemic creates serious problems for “levelling-up”. The cost of supporting the economy through the lockdown will have piled tens of billions onto the national debt. How much room will be left for infrastructure? And will the global economy be stalling or roaring back? That matters for the public finances, but also for the regions that the Tories want to boost. Regenerating post-industrial towns is hard enough without a global recession.But is there a case for optimism? The economic recovery, which many still hope will be swift and dramatic, could provide a significant chance to reorder the economy. The Government has a major task ahead in reaching net-zero emissions by 2050, but it could target the post-virus stimulus not only at lifting up the regions but at transforming public transport, energy production and housing in the process. Here’s hoping.As this lockdown continues, one thing has become apparent to most families in Britain: we need teachers.  On March 20, schools across the UK shut indefinitely to all but the children of key workers in order to help slow the spread of the coronavirus. In an unprecedented move, GCSE and A-level exams will not take place instead, GCSEs, AS and A-levels will be awarded in July based on mock data, inidual assessment and prior attainment. Many have questioned the accuracy of these, particularly for black and minority ethnic, working-class and other marginalised students. Students may also be allowed to sit exams early in the next academic year or in summer 2021.The next three and a half months will bring us up to the end of summer term. The Government has said it will assess the situation after Easter, but most educators in Britain are preparing for the likelihood that schools will remain closed through May and, most likely, through the end of the summer term. While a study released this week by University College London concluded that closing schools may not have a big impact on preventing the spread of Covid-19, most around the world remain shut.What does this mean for learning? On one hand, the British education system is sensibly repetitive. “Homes aren’t schools, and nor should they be,” notes Dr Dan O’Hare, an educational psychologist at the University of Bristol. “They worry is that children need a lot of ‘learning’ - but the curriculum is pretty repetitive and they’ll have covered it before, and will cover it again.”The greater loss during this period is social, says Dr O’Hare. Whether four or 14, children rely on classroom interactions to build and maintain the social skills that will carry them through life. Adolescent development relies on peer identity. To keep that skillset going, Dr O’Hare says social media, with parental supervision, can be a very positive tool.The provision of education at home during this period is deeply uneven, and the degree to which parents are able to lead home-learning has exposed deep isions: while some parents may be organising four hours of focused, supported study each day, others in the same school may be struggling to feed their children.Some educators have taken the cancellation of exams this year as a chance to reconsider the British education system. The UK is alone in Europe in assessing twice (at 16 and 18), and in offering such a narrow range of subjects at the final school assessment level (A-level). Even the inventor of the GCSE has called for them to be scrapped perhaps this period of reflection will allow educators to step back and re-prioritise the outcomes of our education system?Twelve years ago – the last time the global economy was brought to its knees – it was the banks that needed bailing out. This time it’s everyone else: borrowers, savers, renters, homeowners – and yes, even landlords.Politicians and regulators have made it very clear that Britain’s banking system must now repay its debt and support the taxpayers who, as a result of the 2008 crisis, endured austerity and a lost decade of wage growth while property prices took ownership out of the reach of many younger workers.Banks have fallen into line, agreeing various “holidays”, from mortgage payments to extortionate overdraft fees. It seems certain these will now be extended into the next 100 days.I’m afraid the real economic hit will not be fully revealed for some time yet. Currently furloughed workers are having 80 per cent of their wages (up to £2,500 a month) guaranteed by the Government. A much-needed safety net, but one that doesn’t do much to help employers who must stump up the cash today, and claim it back later. At best, this is keeping thousands of firms on life support. When that is withdrawn, we will see unemployment figures soar, in line with the truly terrifying figures coming out of America. It will be far, far worse than the financial crisis.If that does come to pass, payment holidays of all stripes will need to be extended – there’s no chance of unemployed people being able to meet repayments. Applications for Universal Credit, the main out of work and low-income benefit payment, have already surged. Expect another wave in June. Universal Credit has already been increased, to just under £100 a week, and may need to be raised again.Most at risk is Britain’s five million-strong self-employed army. While Rishi Sunak did (eventually) extend his bailout to people who work for themselves, millions are still missing out on any help whatsoever. By mid-summer, what little cash reserves the prudent have set aside may have been burnt through, and struggling businesses will have cut contractors and other third parties to control costs. Mr Sunak has all but confirmed the self-employed will have to pay him back with higher National Insurance costs in the future. Though he may be forced to backtrack, as former chancellor Phillip Hammond was, given this could be seen as a “tax on entrepreneurs”.The self-employed and anyone who fills out a tax return have had a reprieve on this year’s “payments on account”. This second tax deadline will now be due in January 2021, not July this year. More help may be forthcoming when the scale of the challenge facing the sector becomes apparent.  Students and parents of children at nurseries and fee-paying schools face a nervous wait. Will they get any refunds? So far, institutions are resisting particularly where they are offering online services. If the lockdown is still in place in 100 days they may be forced to offer refunds, even if that means they enter dire financial straits.Anyone with a big chunk of their assets in the stock market will be hurting – a lot. The FTSE 100 index of the biggest British companies has lost about a third of its value since the start of the year. Billions of idends have been cut, and will likely not resurface for years. Yet there is a growing case for arguing this is one of the best times in history to be investing. In three months’ time, brand-new investors or people putting their cash into markets now, might already be sitting on healthy profits. Pick the right stocks and in 20 years’ time, well you might just be a surprise entry to the ranks of Isa millionaires.A screenwriter I know claims he has never been so busy  – the film industry has in the last fortnight gone into overdrive, he says, looking for material to fill the gaps that will occur when the lockdown lifts, with every studio determined to be ahead of the game.The same is true throughout the arts. Having rolled out programmes of streamed content to ensure some continuity, the movers and shakers have knuckled down to the conference-call business of forward planning for the autumn and beyond.Not much is likely to happen before September. Glyndebourne still fondly hopes to reopen on 14 July, and at the time of writing the BBC Proms (theoretically kicking off on 17 July) hasn’t yet been canned. But the Edinburgh festival jamboree in August is off, and West End shows aren’t likely to reopen in a hurry when there will be scant traffic, either touristic or domestic.So the focus is now on shifting dates and contracts to counter the loss of short-term income and minimise unnecessary risks: expect the announcement of some extra-long panto runs, and a lot of performances of tried and tested hits such as Carmen, Swan Lake and A Midsummer Night’s Dream. ENO is replacing its autumn Coliseum season with 10 weeks of the musical Hairspray.The good news is that the Chancellor has been quick to recognise the sector’s needs and decent concessions have been made, even if the sums involved are hardly on the German scale of 50 billion euros. Gift Aid can now be claimed on tickets not refunded, and Arts Council England has relaxed National Lottery rules so that money that would otherwise have channeled to capital projects can be used for emergency aid to the arts instead, without cost to the Treasury or the taxpayer. Some extra grant will be necessary for museums not under the ACE umbrella – could its source lie in the £120 million currently allotted to the Brexit Festival of 2022?The biggest challenge facing the arts over the next 100 days is to predict how taste and demand will change as a result of the trauma of the crisis – quite apart from the effect that straitened incomes will have on people’s ability to pay for entertainment. But be in no doubt: the arts are highly resourceful, imaginative and upbeat - and they have an absolutely central role to play in the national recovery.In another world, Glasgow would be gearing up to host the international climate summit COP26 in July, the biggest moment for climate diplomacy since the Paris Agreement was reached in 2015.Its postponement until next year pauses desperately needed international cooperation to keep global warming at 1.5 degrees celsius above pre-industrial levels.That might not be such a bad thing. You will be hard-pressed to find many observers who held out high hopes for the outcome of the summit.The talks will now take place in a changed world.What may turn out to be the greatest impact of the crisis is the overturning of many of the assumptions that underpin our consumption-based emissions. Do we need to fly to that conference, rather than join online? Can we all adjust to working from home more and limiting our car journeys?Meanwhile, it has reminded us of the value of the natural world. Suddenly, we are desperate for the restorative powers of the great outdoors, and the local wildlife has come out of hiding. The zoonotic origins of the disease may prompt a rethink about our relationship to wildlife and bioersity. China is under pressure to permanently ban wildlife markets, believed to be the source of the virus.Already we can see the benefit to the environment of our changed behaviour. Carbon emissions and air pollution have dipped during the shutdown China’s annual CO2 emissions are estimated to have fallen 18 per cent. Air travel is down more than half.Clearly, these cuts are unsustainable in the current mode and are likely to bounce back, as we have already seen in China, unless they are translated into long-term changes.Questions over how we will rebuild have rightly largely been put aside for the time being as the world focuses on saving lives and getting back to work. But in 100 days we will start to see more conversations about where we want to focus our resources and whether the post-Covid stimulus packages should be invested toward a greener world.The prospects for that are mixed, so far. The response in the US is likely to be decided in the November presidential election. Already Donald Trump has relaxed environmental requirements for the fossil fuel industry, citing the crisis.China has also relaxed some environmental regulations and early indicators suggest it has ramped up production in those areas of the country where the lockdown has eased.The EU has said it remains committed to its Green Deal, but there have been calls from Poland and the Czech Republic for it to be put on hold.The other big question for the next few weeks is what role will international cooperation play? Should we start to see a united front in the fight against this virus, it may reinforce the power of collaboration to face a common challenge. Again there, so far, the outlook is not rosy.For many, the anxiety set in slowly. As people washed their hands to the tune of Happy Birthday with one eye on the news, talk of mass death and draconian lockdowns started to fill our social media feeds. It sounded hysterical at first, but it wasn’t long before all our lives had changed beyond recognition. 100 days in, and our so-called “new normal” has left us with a mental health crisis which is gathering speed.It’s no surprise given how much has changed. We are now unable to see and touch our loved ones, even when they are dying. We don gloves and masks for the occasional nervous visit to the supermarket, we are at risk of being shouted at by police on our daily government-sanctioned hour of exercise, and we hover over our finances and food supplies with trepidation. All those little routines we never used to think about - the quiet building blocks for our resilience - shattered in a matter of weeks. Meanwhile, we live in fear of an invisible virus and obsess over symptoms lists.Public Health England’s guidance on how to cope with this brave new world includes maintaining contact with friends and family via the telephone, video calls or social media, keeping to a regular sleeping pattern, and focusing on a hobby. It’s perfectly sensible advice, but it can’t come close to addressing the damage this crisis is doing to our mental health.A recent Ipsos-MORI poll revealed 62 per cent of Britons were finding it harder to stay positive about the future in the face of the pandemic. Meanwhile 80 per cent of young people with a history of mental ill health have found their conditions have worsened since the crisis began. Distressing reports coming from Covid wards suggest there may be many frontline workers, survivors of the virus, and bereaved families requiring mental health support in the coming months.One hundred days in, we still don’t know when this will end, nor how, and it’s impossible to predict exactly where we might be 100 days from now. But while we can’t control what happens in the coming weeks and months, we can try to get a handle on how we react to all this. Mind, which was given a £5 million grant by the Government last week to administer to mental health charities around the country, advises that we all take extra steps to help combat anxiety during this period.Take a break from the news cycle maintain social contact stay hydrated, well fed, mentally stimulated and physically active keep taking your medication if you are on any (if you have a repeat prescription you might be able to order it by phone, online or using an app, and your GP can still have an appointment with you over the phone) and above all don’t leave it too long to seek help. Start by talking about how you feel with someone you trust. Start today.I don’t have to look far to find a picture of how exercise has changed over the past 100 days. As I write these words from the shed at the bottom of my garden, I can see my neighbour doing inverted press-ups, using TRX bands that he’s strung from the back of his house. Inside my own house, my partner and kids are learning ‘spidey squats’ with Joe Wicks on YouTube. Later, I’m hoping to nip out for an hour on my bike, to take advantage of the empty roads. On a weekday.The last time I checked, before coronavirus made its way to the UK, we were in the doldrums of February - a time of hibernation and cancelled gym subscriptions. Now, a few weeks later, it’s as though we’re back in the heady days of early January, intent on working off the excesses of Christmas. Exercise is everywhere and we’re not deterred by barriers from getting it. Yoga studio closed down? No problem: we’ll do a class over Zoom. London Marathon cancelled? Who cares: we’ll run it virtually. Gym doors shut? What you want is Wicks on the TV, or some TRX bands in your garden.The question for the next 100 days is simple: will we keep going? New Year, New You health kicks tend to slide into guilty deferrals (‘next year, new me’). So how resolute is this current trend?I have hope. All around us, exercise is being reframed as an expression of our freedom. When it’s the one thing you can do outside every day, going for a run or a ride feels less like a chore, more like something that’s actually quite fun. The lockdown might not be in place in 100 days' time, but perhaps the reminder that exercise makes us feel good, and it's freely (or easily) available to everyone, will stay in our minds?The gym industry is going to have to work out where it fits in this new, more egalitarian world of exercise. The traditional gym certainly won’t die - you’ll always have people who want to work out away from their own homes, and the hardcore bunnies who love the wrought iron atmosphere - but expect big chains to start competing for the online class space. And don’t be surprised if you see personal trainers trying their luck here either: online workouts offer a way for them to teach clients without having to pay rent or commission to a gym landlord. Embrace Zoom, and you might just find your weekly PT session dropping in price.For the nation’s backbone of small and medium-sized businesses, surviving the next 100 days will be an achievement in itself.  They are adaptable and resilient, but few businesses could emerge unscathed from the plunge in demand triggered by the coronavirus lockdown.From cheesecake makers in Preston to door-makers in Buckingham and car-parts makers in Worcester, erse businesses are facing the same stark question: How can you carry on, when the customers have disappeared?Added to the practical problems of poorly staff and looking after their own families, life in recent weeks has been a difficult haze for the millions of striving bosses in this crucial sector which supports 22m employees.Much of their energy since the national lockdown on March 23 has been spent trying to navigate the financial support put in place by the government - on hold with banks, haggling with landlords over rent holidays, deferring VAT payments, or talking to equally stressed suppliers.Only once those conversations have taken place and options are exhausted will it become clearer which businesses will make it through. Insolvency practitioners are braced for a wave of business once bosses work out where they stand.It's clear the government support will not solve all of businesses’ problems, even with the welcome improvements to the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme that were introduced at the start of April, and pressure on banks to lend.Many companies are reluctant to borrow given the uncertainty over how quickly demand will recover. Putting staff on government-funded paid leave is helping bosses avoid lay-offs, but doesn’t help those who still need workers to help re-right the business, but cannot afford to pay them.Given the shock to demand, there is stress on all sides, and no easy way out. Legal challenges loom between suppliers and customers, tenants and landlords. Radical solutions being floated -  such as getting stronger companies to take over struggling rivals or the government taking equity stakes - are likely to gain more traction.Yet the simple biggest help to many companies would be some clearer guidance about when lockdown might be lifted - for financial planning as much as a psychological boost to bosses thinking about throwing in the towel. Hence ministerial attempts to dodge questions about the exit strategy are exasperating.In the meantime, companies will need to adapt, and many are already doing so. Many are selling vouchers for when they re-open making use of back-up supply chains organised during preparations for a no-deal Brexit opening up new online sales channels or even putting resources at the use of the NHS.There is hope then, that July 18 will be marked by successes along with the inevitable defeats.As the world has ground to a halt, virtually all travel companies are facing an existential threat. March would normally have been an important month for advance bookings - airlines and operators rake in cash as people book ahead for their spring and summer holidays. Instead, the vast majority of flights have been grounded and the industry - from hotels to airlines - has spent the last five or six weeks trying to cope with a deluge of cancellations and requests for refunds.Without more help from the government or a sudden change in fortune, significant numbers seem certain to collapse under the financial strain. We are likely to end up with fewer travel agencies, tour operators and - probably -  airlines too. We may well see some big names go under.But the one thing which would help save the bulk of the industry is the main summer holiday season. As chance would have it, the next 100 days of Covid-19 will take us to July 18. That’s just before most schools are expected to break up for the summer - assuming they return in the meantime. It is peak time for nearly all holiday companies - the six weeks or so when they make their key revenues for the year.The prospect of a successful summer is now on a knife edge and depends on two things. First that lockdown is a success, not just in the UK but also in the key Mediterranean holiday destinations, and it can be relaxed sufficiently to allow international travel. And second, that people feel confident - and solvent - enough to take a foreign holiday. Given the chance, the travel trade will no doubt attempt to drive bookings by offering exceptionally good deals. Even so, they are likely to have a battle on their hands to win back custom.France seems likely to be one testing ground. Once restrictions are lifted, we may see the first shoots of recovery among British travellers taking their own cars across the Channel. But the recovery of air travel will be crucial. Some airlines - Jet2 for example - say they will start flying again on May 1. Ryanair and British Airways look more realistic in planning for a significant increase in services from June onwardsBritain’s biggest tour operator, TUI is allowing customers to postpone existing bookings made before the end of June. Clearly it is hopeful to be able to operate during those key months of July and August.In short, the timing looks incredibly tight. If we are to avoid a lost summer of foreign holidays and the decimation of the travel industry, the battle against Covid-19 needs to go seamlessly.The prospects for holidays in this country look more rosy, however. Assuming travel restrictions in the UK are lifted relatively soon, hotels, holiday cottages, camping and caravan sites should be well back on track by mid July. Given the pent up demand from a public driven stir-crazy by lockdown, this summer may be boom-time for British holidays.So far, coronavirus has frozen the housing market, begun a mass withdrawal of mortgage options and halted most major housebuilding projects. Buyers and sellers have been thrown into a painful limbo. And many have started to worry seriously about house prices.So what’s next? First, transactions are going to tank. The government has effectively banned house sales unless buyers and sellers are legally bound to go ahead. In some weeks in April and May, Capital Economics forecasts falls in mortgage approvals and transactions of more than 90 per cent year-on-year. This would match what happened in China during lockdown. Overall, across the next three months, the research firm expects a 70 per cent drop in sales compared to the same period in 2019. Sales are unlikely to resurge fast after lockdown has been lifted. Savills has based its predictions on an assumption that transactions will stay at as much as 40 per cent below their five year average until September. Estate agents’ commission books are going to take a nasty hit.But that is not the same as a house price crash. It is in fact possible that so few transactions will take place that there won’t be enough data to produce some house price indexes.When the lockdown lifts, some purchases that were put on hold will go ahead as previously planned, but everyone in the market will be newly cautious - buyers of getting into negative equity and vendors of under-selling. We will almost certainly be in a recession. Stock levels will be low, but some people will have to take price cuts and sell. Savills forecasts a short-term price drop of between 5 and 10 per cent.Still, the number of forced sellers should be low. The Government has made swift measures to protect jobs, earnings and home ownership. Airbnb landlords, who will have lost their cash flow with the collapse of the travel industry, will find themselves on a pressure point. In 100 days, we will have seen a mass influx of these properties first to the long-term lettings market, and then perhaps to sales. But far more home owners should be stable than in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.Then, as with the crash in the early Nineties, the house price plunge followed a period of exponential growth. This time around, our market was not volatile but tentatively recovering from a low base. Many buyers who currently have transactions on hold haven’t thought about renegotiating because they had already got themselves, say, a 10 per cent discount. There isn’t the same cliff edge to fall off. Overall for 2020, both Capital Economics and Knight Frank forecast price falls of only 3 per cent, with recovery starting in 2021.This was meant to be the year Boris Johnson would get Brexit done on January 31, and dusted on December 31 by seeing the United Kingdom out of its transition period on time.The first part of the Prime Minister’s plan went off without a hitch, thanks to his election win helping him steamroller parliamentary opposition. But his hefty Commons majority has not been able to stop Covid-19 from throwing a ner in the works of the post-Brexit talks.After negotiators faced off in their first round of talks at the start of March, the UK and EU had to ert increasing amounts of money, manpower and attention to the raging pandemic rather than preparing for life fully outside of the bloc. Coronavirus soon made it unsafe for negotiators to meet in person, with Michel Barnier and his British counterpart David Frost having to lie low after showing symptoms of the disease.With negotiators reduced to a back and forth of emails and attempts to make the most with remote communication technology, progress has been glacial. Talks have little advanced from opening demands. But in less than 100 days, both sides have to decide if they want to extend the transition period in order to allow more time to negotiate their future relationship.Before coronavirus reared its ugly head, Boris Johnson threatened in February to ramp up preparations to leave without a deal unless negotiators made enough progress by June, nailing down key areas like fisheries and financial services. With the sufficient progress now nigh-on impossible, barring a last-minute erasure of red lines in a desperate grab for a deal, the Prime Minister will have to decide how ready he is to make good on that threat.Meanwhile, European politicians are piling pressure on him to seek a delay, knowing well how vehemently he ruled out such an idea.The UK Government insists for now that it will not budge in its refusal to string out negotiations, but even stalwart Brexiteers are bracing themselves privately for such a delay to be agreed. Expect it only to happen at the very last minute ahead of the July deadline, when it is beyond doubt how badly Covid-19 has disrupted everything.Coronavirus has already struck down the Prime Minister, UK and EU negotiators and any chance of both sides steaming towards a good deal by July. Mr Johnson will be fighting until the last minute not to have its cherished transition deadline enter its own “delay phase”.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: many people may already have immunity coronavirus german study
story: Many more people may have been infected with the coronavirus and acquired immunity than previously thought, according to a groundbreaking study in Germany.Scientists studying the town at the epicentre of Germany's first major outbreak said they had found antibodies to the virus in people who had shown no symptoms and were not previously thought to have been infected.Initial results released on Thursday suggest as many as 15 per cent of the town may already have immunity — three times as many as previous estimates.The findings suggest the mortality rate for the virus in Germany is just 0.37 per cent — five times lower than current estimates.“This means a gradual relaxation of the lockdown is now possible,” Prof Hendrik Streeck, the virologist leading the study told a press conference.“Because the people in Germany have been so careful and disciplined, we are now able to move on to the second phase.”But Angela Merkel dashed hopes of an early end to the lockdown, telling Germans: “We must not be reckless now. We could very quickly destroy what we have achieved.”The study in the town of Gangelt in Heinsberg district is the first in Europe to research the effects of the virus on an entire community.Scientists from the University of Bonn are testing around 1,000 people from 400 households for antibodies as well as signs of current infection.Initial results based on around half the tests found 2 per cent of inhabitants are currently infected and 14 per cent had antibodies to the virus. Allowing for overlap that suggests 15 per cent of people in the town now have immunity — compared to the previous estimate of 5 per cent.The 15 percent is not that far from the 60 per cent we need for herd immunity, Prof Gunther Hartmann, another of the study's leaders, said.“With 60 to 70 per cent herd immunity, the virus will completely disappear from the population. Then the elderly are no longer at risk.”The figures cannot be extrapolated to the rest of Germany because Gangelt had a higher rate of infection. But the study's authors said they were grounds for cautious optimism.  An immunity rate of 15 per cent is already enough to slow the spread of the virus significantly, they said in a joint statement.The findings suggest the mortality rate of the virus may be lower than previously thought. The study found a mortality rate of 0.37 per cent, compared to Johns Hopkins University’s current estimate for Germany of 1.98 per cent.The study's authors said their findings could be closer to the real figure for the virus because they had detected so many previously unknown infections.“The much lower mortality rate in Gangelt is explained by the fact this study is detecting all infected people, including those with no symptoms or very mild illness,” they said.Antibody testing for the virus is still in its early stages. Chinese scientists released a study confirming they had detected antibodies for the first time this week, but warned they were unable to detect any in some patients known to have been infected.It is unclear how long any immunity to the virus conferred by a previous infection will last, although experience with similar viruses suggests it will be in the range of a year to 18 months.“I think the most important thing all governments can do to address the virus is to get reliable data,” Prof Streeck, the study leader, told the . “We don’t yet know enough about this virus.”The study’s authors said the findings were grounds to begin lifting the current general lockdown and move on to a phase of isolating the vulnerable groups most at risk.Jens Spahn, the German health minister, earlier suggested an easing of the lockdown could be possible after Easter “We are seeing a positive trend, but it must continue,” Mr Spahn said. “If it does, we will be able to talk… about a gradual return to normality after the Easter holidays.”But Mrs Merkel appeared to play down hopes for an early easing of restrictions amid concerns people may be less disciplined about social distancing over the Easter holidays.“I would like to be the first to tell you everything is as it was and we can go back to normal, but that’s not how it is, she said.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: popes representativ lockdown enables us focus true needs instead
story: The Pope’s representative in England and Wales has said that the pandemic lockdown is an opportunity to reassess our priorities and focus on our true needs instead of fleeting desires. On Easter Sunday Cardinal Vincent Nichols, the Archbishop of Westminster, will broadcast a special service on BBC Local Radio stations. His sermon will focus on the impact of coronavirus and how it is a chance for us to “reset our sights” and reassess our priorities and that “in a time of darkness and anxiety”.He will say: “Today, we can reset our sights, focussing on our true needs and on our finest gifts. “This time of great testing enables us to distinguish what is truly important from all that is fleetingly desired and has so often mistakenly beene given pride of place in our ambitions. “Already we have to look forward to the rebuilding of our common life, may the light of the risen Christ guide and inspire us in that task.” Cardinal Nichols will also include comments from a frontline doctor who will talk about her experience of being with people who are dying and a civil servant who will discuss the rebuilding of the nation in the wake of the pandemic.The Catholic leader will be offering his sermon at a time when all religious buildings and places of worship have been forced to close in order to curb the spread of coronavirus.He will also say in his sermon: “This truth of Christ’s rising from the dead gives us courage to face the cold embrace of death with great trust in the promise of Jesus, that he will bring us with him into a life more powerful than death and more glorious too.” The Easter sermon will be held on Sunday morning 8am on all 39 BBC local radio stations and will be available on BBC Sounds afterwards.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: us firm claims can deliver matt hancocks promise 100000 coronavirus
story: A single US firm has claimed it is on track to deliver Matt Hancock’s target of 100,000 coronavirus tests every day by the end of the month.Thermo Fisher Scientific, based in Massachusetts, said it had the capacity to deliver all the tests needed to hit the Health Secretary’s ambitious target laid out last week.The company has signed a major deal with the Government to ramp up tests at a laboratory in Milton Keynes, and said it would work around the clock to hit the deadline.In recent weeks the Government has faced heavy criticism as Britain's mass testing programme continues to lag far behind other nations including Germany and South Korea – as  illustrated in the below graph from earlier this week.In response, the Health Secretary last week launched a five-pillar strategy to ramp up testing in the UK to 100,000 every day by the end of the month.The  revealed on Thursday how NHS leaders told the Health Secretary during a frank conference call on Wednesday that their current testing targets would be jam tomorrow without significant outside help.Mark Stevenson, chief operating officer at Thermo Fisher Scientific, said his firm alone could deliver the target by the end of April. The company will also initially produce antigen tests to tell people whether they have the virus.Mr Stevenson told the BBC: We began mobilising actually straight away after we learned about the Covid-19 outbreak and we designed the kit to identify the virus's unique genetic code.Then we worked in a way to test that, validate that in patients. And then we began to scale up our manufacturing to meet demand.We agreed with the UK that we would supply to meet their demand of more than 100,000 tests per day.Mr Stevenson said the kits are currently produced outside the UK but the firm had agreed to use its UK bases to produce kits for local supply.Here in the UK we have about 5,000 employees and about 26 sites, so we already have a very large presence, he said.Mr Stevenson said Amazon was involved in moving the test kits from the firm's bases to UK testing centres.In recent days ministers have unveiled major partnerships with private firms and universities after admitting that NHS labs alone would not be able to plug the gap in testing.The pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca aims to deliver a validated Covid-19 antibody test by the beginning of May that could be scaled up by the end of that month, its UK president said on Thursday.Tom Keith-Roach said the focus is on antigen tests, which can tell people whether they have the virus, but work is also ongoing on an antibody test.Antibody tests are seen as a vital route out of lockdown, enabling those who have had the the virus to resume normal life and get back to work.AstraZeneca, Cambridge University and GlaxoSmithKline have joined forces for a testing facility in Cambridge with the aim of delivering 30,000 antigen tests by the start of May.AstraZeneca and GSK are supporting three other testing centres in Milton Keynes, Alderley Park and Glasgow.Mr Keith-Roach said pharmaceutical firms are working together in the national interest to overcome global supply problems with the chemicals and swabs needed for testing.He said testing kits have 79 components, including reagents and other chemicals, and six are subject to constraints.On each of those six components and swabs, we're working with the Government, we're working with GSK, he said.We all obviously have global supply chains that reach into China, that reach into all of our trading partners around the world.Experts are also looking at alternative reagents or alternative components to deal with and mitigate some of those risks, he said.But at this stage, we're confident that we're going to have the capacity to do 30,000 a day and that's why we felt able to make that commitment.Mr Keith-Roach said the aim is for antigen and antibody tests to be carried out by people in their own homes.Clinicians across the country are trying to do absolutely everything possible right now to keep patients out of the healthcare system and to deliver diagnostics of care at home – to not expose patients for unnecessary risk, he said. That will be the principle here.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus farming jobs search record feed nation campaign
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Tens of thousands apply for agricultural work after warnings over fruit picker shortageMore than 30,000 people have applied for farming jobs after a campaign to feed the nation began two weeks ago.Jobs websites said they had seen record numbers of searches for farm work including fruit picking since farmers put out the call for extra staff.The UK faces an imminent shortage of labour, with many of the migrant workers who typically do seasonal farm work unable to travel from their home countries due to restrictions put in place during the coronavirus pandemic.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesConcordia, the charity tasked with filling the gap, said 30,000 people had expressed an interest and around 2,000 were currently being matched to roles on farms.Almost nine in 10 of those who have applied are UK citizens and less than one-third have a farming background. About half of applicants were seeking work after losing their livelihoods due to Covid-19, Concordia said.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastThe latest round of jobs will start from the beginning of May when the UK's soft fruit season begins with harvests of strawberries, raspberries and other summer fruits.Recruitment website Totaljobs has reported a record 50,000 searches for farm jobs last week. Searches for fruit picker and farm worker rose 330 per cent and 107 per cent respectively.The site has seen an 83 per cent jump in job applications for agricultural work over the past month.Steve Warnham of Totaljobs said he had noticed a trend of workers who have been temporarily displaced due to COVID-19 who are now looking for roles they can take on in other sectors to keep Britain moving.Other jobs designated as key by the government, including healthcare and logistics, have also seen a surge in interest.Mark Bridgeman, president of the Country Land and Business said it was wonderful news that tens of thousands of people had come forward but warned that many more were needed.“We all know this is a deeply concerning period and we are all determined to do all we can to help the country through it. In order to do so, we must recognise that farmers supply of labour is in jeopardy, he said.A shortage of 80,000 workers is something we have never seen before. This is why we are calling for a ‘Land Army’ of workers to support farmers in feeding the country.”The campaign comes in the midst of one of the sharpest rises in unemployment on record, with more than a million new universal credit claims registered over the past three weeks despite government efforts to keep people in jobs by paying wages.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: uk economy gdp latest coronavirus ons data
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The UK economy contracted in February as poor weather impacted the construction sector, according to official statisticians.The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said UK GDP fell by 0.1 per cent during the month, as it slipped from 0.1 per cent growth in January.Economists had predicted that the economy would in fact grow by 0.1 per cent in February.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe ONS said the figures, which cover the period before the spread of coronavirus accelerated across the UK, reflected continued stagnation in the economy.Declining activity in the construction industry particularly hampered growth, with the sector reporting a 1.7 per cent decline in its GDP for February.Meanwhile, the services sector was flat, manufacturing grew by 0.5 per cent and the agriculture sector reported a 0.1 per cent decline for the month.The ONS also revealed that GDP grew by 0.1 per cent in the three months to February, on the back of growth in December and January.It said growth for the quarter was driven by a positive period for the service sector, although the industry is expected to show a sharp decline in the next set of figures, following the Government-mandated shutdown of pubs, bars and restaurants.Rob Kent-Smith, head of GDP at the ONS, said: “Today's figures show that in the three months to February, which was before the full effects of coronavirus took hold, the economy continued to show little to no growth.Most elements of the services sector grew, though manufacturing continued to decline.“Construction saw a notable fall in February, as wet weather and flooding hampered housebuilding.”Fran Boait, executive director of Positive Money, said: “There is a risk that as growth figures get worse, the government will be pressured to relax coronavirus prevention measures to get the economy going again, at the expense of lives.Office for National Statistics&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The message we are getting is if we don’t take care of nature, it will take care of us,’ Elizabeth&nbspMaruma&nbspMrema saysAn international ban on wildlife markets could help stop future pandemics like coronavirus from breaking out, according to the United Nations&nbspbioersity chief.The Covid-19 outbreak is believed to have originated in a&nbspseafood market in the central Chinese city of&nbspWuhan, where it is thought stallholders were infected during contact with animals on sale.Previous epidemics have also begun&nbspwith animal-to-human transmission, including severe acute respiratory syndrome (Sars), which infected&nbspmore than 8,000 people between 2002 and 2003.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesElizabeth Maruma Mrema, acting executive secretary of the UN's&nbspbiological ersity department, has said&nbspbanning markets where live animals are sold for human consumption&nbspcould prevent new pandemic diseases from spreading. However, she said such restrictions should only be imposed in the right conditions.“The message we are getting is if we don’t take care of nature, it will take care of us,” Ms&nbspMrema&nbsptold&nbsp.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus Podcast“It would be good to ban the live animal markets as China has done and some countries. But we should also remember you have communities, particularly from low-income rural areas, particularly in Africa, which are dependent on wild animals to sustain the livelihoods of millions of people,” she said.“Unless we get alternatives for these communities, there might be a danger of opening up illegal trade in wild animals which currently is already leading us to the brink of extinction for some species.”China temporarily banned people&nbspfrom eating and trading wildlife&nbspfor food earlier this year&nbspas the country&nbspworked to combat the spread of coronavirus.​Humane Society International, an animal charity, has&nbspcalled for this ban to become a permanent fixture across the globe.“The capture and consumption of wild animals is a global trade that causes immense suffering for hundreds of thousands of animals every year, including endangered wildlife species being traded to the brink of extinction,” said president Jeffrey Flocken.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Created with Sketch.Pink supermoon lights up the night sky: In pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Biggest and brightest moon of the year so far was in full view on Tuesday nightPeople across the UK were drawn to their windows and gardens on Tuesday evening as&nbspa pink supermoon&nbsprose over the night sky.Many&nbspgrabbed their cameras and smartphones to try to record the lunar light show, which saw the biggest and brightest moon of the year so far.Twitter users posted their attempts to capture the view&nbspand to share their delight at the “amazing” and “beautiful” phenomenon.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesDespite its name, there is not any noticeable colour difference to the full moon, which was set to reach its peak at 3:55am on Wednesday.The pink supermoon name is a northern Native American reference to an early-blooming wildflower, which is first seen in the US and Canada at the beginning of spring.Nasa asks for applications to go to the MoonIn some other cultures, the pink moon is known as the sprouting grass moon, the egg moon, and the fish moon.One Twitter user wrote: “If anyone needs a moment of calm, take a look at the moon right now.”The moon&nbspappeared up to 14 per cent&nbspbigger and 30 per cent brighter than usual in the sky as it reached&nbspits closest point to Earth, known as its perigee.April's supermoon is the third of the year, and largest so far, following the worm moon on 9 March.The next full moon is referred to as the Flower Moon, which takes place on 7 May.Additional reporting by Press AssociationBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: supermoon 2020 flower full moon when next date may
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.May will be the the last chance to see the celestial event until 2021The final supermoon of 2020 will take place next month, offering sky gazers one last chance to see the full moon at its biggest and brightest.The rare celestial event – officially referred to as a perigean moon – will see the moon pass by Earth at the closest point of its monthly orbit.On 7 May, the full moon will pass within 360,000km (224,000 miles)&nbspof Earth, making it the fourth moon in a row to be classed as a supermoon.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe time of year means May's full moon is also traditionally known as a Flower Moon, as it coincides with spring blossoms in the northern hemisphere.April's supermoon is known in folklore as the Pink Moon, and lit up the skies over the UK unusually brightly thanks to good weather and lower-than-average air pollution.How to take the perfect picture of the supermoonEven without a telescope or binoculars, it was possible to view craters, basins and other features due to its proximity to Earth.The moon appeared at its largest at moonrise and moonset as a result of an optical illusion that makes it seem relatively bigger when viewed beside buildings and other objects on the horizon.Created with Sketch.Pink supermoon lights up the night sky: In pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.May's supermoon&nbspwill also have an effect on the Earth's ocean, with the extra gravitational pull causing extra-high tides in the days following its closest pass.This can occasionally result in coastal flooding, though only when it coincides with severe weather events.According to long range forecasts by the Met Office, the weather for early May is not expected to be particularly unsettled.Although confidence is low during this time period, the most probable scenario is that dry weather should dominate, with some interludes of more changeable weather at times, the weather agency stated.Towards the end of the period, there appears to be some signals that it may be more unsettled towards the north of the UK, with drier weather to the south.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter
