title: dj flogging coronavirus test snapchat
story: A LONDON DJ has been advertising coronavirus testing kits for sale on social media despite experts warning such tests shouldnt be used at home, Sun Online has discovered.DJ Enay posted Snapchat and Instagram notices promising “Covid- test kits for sale” with “rapid results within  minutes”.One photo uploaded by the garage and grime DJ shows stacked boxes of Covid- test kits.Another image showed the Covid- blood testing kit by Dutch-based company Biozek with an arrow indicating how to use it.The tests are approved for sale and professional use in the UK and EU certied, another post from the DJ says.“Potential results” include discoveringyou are COVID  negative or in the early, middle or late stages of the virus.The rapid result kits have “. per cent accuracy compared to  per cent accuracy in Chinese kits Last month, the Spanish government had to withdraw a batch of faulty coronavirus test kits it bought from China as they only had  per cent accuracy.The antibody test kits the DJ is advertising can also “check for early, mid and late stages of the virus”, he says.Antibody blood tests can detectsomeone has had the virus and recovered.In one Snapchat post, the London-based DJ tells his followers “price change for Covid- test kits. Stay Tuned”.Other items being flogged on the DJ’s social media pages include parrots and £ T-shirts.DJ Enays Facebook page describes him as “one of the fastest growing talents amongst the international clubland”.When Sun Online contacted him to ask about the posts advertising coronavirus testing kits they were immediately removed from his social media pages.At the time of going to publication he had not yet responded to our questions.A concerned person who saw the DJ’s posts on Snapchat told Sun Online: “This is ridiculous considering the shortages of testing kits available in the UK!“With nurses and doctors suffering frontline, as well as key workers such as teachers unable to go back to work as they are unsurethey have it or not.”The scramble to test frontline NHS staff comes as Britains death toll climbed today to , with  more deaths in  hours.At least  NHS doctors and nurses have died in the battle against the disease.Last week, it was revealed just , out of , NHS staff had been tested for the deadly bug, despite government promises to ramp up testing for frontline medical staff.Health Secretary Matt Hancocks target of , tests a day in England by the end of April is unlikely to be met, experts have warned.Coronavirus antibody testing kits currently on the market are only approved for use by health professionals.Biozek, the Dutch-based company that manufactures the kits shown in the DJ’s adverts, said its rapid tests are “Dutch made with CE mark.”Manufacturers selling medical devices in the EU need a CE mark to show compliance with health, safety and environmental protection standards.But manufacturers are responsible for declaring conformity with all requirements and a CE-mark is not proof of third-party testing.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency , the UK’s medicine regulator,  confirmed that there are no CE-marked tests for home use, and it is illegal to supply such products.An MHRA spokesman said: “The products in the images from the social media posts were made by Biozek.These products are CE marked and can be marketed for professional use only.There are other CE marked antibody tests available but all are for professional use only and should not be purchased for inidual or home use.The MHRA has conducted regulatory checks on the products in question, but it is important to note that we do not confirm that these products have been reviewed for performance or validity.Last month, Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced the UK had bought . million of the antibody fingerprick test kits to tellpeople had had coronavirus.Swab tests currently used in UK hospitals can tellsomeone currently has the virus.The government placed provisional orders for . million antibody tests promising frontline doctors and nurses would be given priority.On March , the kits were hailed as a game changer which could be rolled out to the public within days.A target of , tests a day in England was also set for the end of April.But last week, it was revealed just , out of , NHS staff had been tested for the deadly bug.And antibody tests to see who has had Covid- wont be ready until May at the earliest, it was announced this week.Professor John Newton, of Public Health England, said that no tests trialled had produced accurate enough results yet.He said: We were optimistic that a number of companies have been offering us these quick antibody tests and we were hoping they would be fit for purpose.They all work to some extent, but are not good enough to rely on.Kathy Hall, director of the Department of Healths Covid- testing strategy, said the government is now trying to get a refund.She said: “We’re now working with companies to cancel the orders and get the money back where possible.The Biozek test kits are for sale on one medical website at £ “for professional   business use only”.Last Friday, Biozeks website said its Covid- rapid test cassette was “being used by Dutch Ministry of Defence, Ministry of Health of Andorra and Kuwait”.A spokesman for the Dutch Ministry of Defence told Sun Online: “Biozek has brought a fast testing kit for corona on the market by a Dutch importer.“The Dutch Ministry of Defence is looking at the applicability of this test.The spokesman added later: We havent actually used the test yet. We are looking at the applicability of this test.A spokesman for the Government of Andorra told Sun Online: I can confirm that our Ministry of Health used  tests sold by Biozek at the beginning of March.After that, we switch to another company.After Sun Online contacted Biozek to ask about its kits being used in Holland, Andorra and Kuwait that sentence was removed from the company’s website.Biozek hadnt responded to emails at the time of publication.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lockdown stricter bank holiday sturgeon
story: BRITAINS lockdown could get even stricterBrits go out on Bank Holiday with Nicola Sturgeon declaring there is no possibility of relaxing  the measures.Scotlands First Minister made the announcement ahead of the stand-in Prime Minister Dominic Raab chairing an emergency Cobra meeting on extending the lockdown.The Foreign Secretary will this afternoon hear advice on the impact of the restrictions so far.Speaking this morning, Ms Sturgeon said: I dont think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately, or even imminently.I wouldnt expect any change coming out of todays Cobra meeting but we will see where the discussions take us.Her comments came as the Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden warned they could even be enhanced.He said: Of course when we have the opportunity to change it, we will, but that is not the moment now.Cobra will meet today to determine that process and what evidence to consider.We said we would review them after three weeks. But reviewing them isn’t saying we will stop them. They remain in place until they change.We’ll be analysing that evidence and determining appropriate stage at which to either enhance or change the measures we are taking.A senior government source backed up Mr Dowdens threat to enhance the lockdown measurespeople flout social distancing rules this weekend, telling the Sun: We are keeping options open and firmly on the table.Ministers fear relaxing the lockdown too soon could kill many thousands more, with the peak of the virus thought to still be ten days away — on April .The daily death toll in the UK hit  yesterday, with , total cases reported by the NHS.At least five police chief constables are said to have already asked ministers to consider being tougher with the public.According to , options include preventing people driving long distances and a law to enforce the Government’s one exercise a day limit.A senior officer complained: “People are still driving for a long time under the excuse of ‘exercise’, and to places they do not need to be.The Easter bank holiday is one of the busiest times of the year. I have no new powers for this weekend.Yesterday Chancellor Rishi Sunak slapped down demands for a timeline to end the lockdown.He told the Downing Street press conference: “Rather than speculate about the future, we should focus here and now on the present.Before falling ill, Boris Johnson pledged to review the lockdown on Easter Monday, April  — three weeks after it began on March .But Downing Street is seriously concerned that people may defy advice and head out to enjoy the C bank holiday sunshine.Mr Raab will today give a firm indication that Brits can expect to be locked down for weeks longer and will again urge them to stay indoors as much as possible.The Government will then formally set an extension early next week — after analysing three weeks’ data.A senior Government source said yesterday: “Nobody is going to argue about extending the lockdown into May.“Look at where the peak is now expected.It’s becoming obvious that’s where we’re heading.“It would be seriously negligent not to do that.”A senior minister added: “The peak is forecast for April .“Only after that can we even begin to think about a controlled step down. title: amazing cloud snap
story: Pete Austin, , was having a cup of tea with his we Jane, , when he locked eyes on the unusual formation out of their kitchen window in Higham Ferrers, Northants.He dashed into the back garden and snapped a picture on his iPhone before the clouds floated away.Mr Austin, who shared the pic online, said the uplting image was a sign there is “light at the end of the tunnel” as Britain fights the coronavirus crisis.The retired NHS care manager said: I was chatting to Jane at the kitchen table when I glanced out the window and saw this familiar shape in the sky.I said thats the British Isles in the clouds and the sun was behind it creating an almost silver-lining on the outside.I grabbed my phone and went outside and just had time to take one shot before the clouds moved and the shape was gone.At a time when the country really needs some hope, I like to believe it showed that there is light at the end of the tunnel.As a former NHS worker I understand just how hard the health service staff are working. title: tearful girl after mum loses job coronavirus
story: A TEARFUL schoolgirl has begged for “things to go back to normal” in an emotional video after her mum lost her job because of the coronavirus crisis.Madison Williams, , from Derbyshire, broke down in tears as she admitted her mum Alexandra, , wasn’t “earning any money”.The youngster recorded her plea for support on her mum’s phone after both her parents lost their jobs.In the clip, later shared on Twitter, she says: “I am really scared and worried because at the minute loads of people in my country and other countries have coronavirus, more than ,, and its just really scary.“My mum doesnt have a job at the minute and shes not earning any money, and my dads works shut down so hes not earning any money”.Madison adds: If anyones seen this that has kids or is a parent to a young child, I really need your help by saying that well get through together because I dont think its fair on any parent that cant go to work or is losing their job because of this.“Theyve worked so hard for their career and stuff. And theyre not going to be getting any money so they really wont be able to pay like, the water, the bills, the gas, the electric, and thats quite a bit of money.“So please,anyone sees this, help us out and do us a favour. I really just hope everything goes back to normal soon.”Madison also said she can’t wait to get back to school because she misses her friends.The school girl tells the camera: “Its my last year at primary school and this is not how I want to end it.“So please, make everything go back to normal, Boris. We believe in you.”Madison’s mum Alexandra works in telesales but was left in dire straits after being told by her boss she did not qualy for furlough pay.She broke down when she found the clip on her phone and shared it on Twitter to support the #newstarterfurlough campaign.The movement wants Chancellor Rishi Sunak to allow those who started jobs after February  to qualy for furlough pay.She tweeted: “I cant speak at the minute. I have just found this on her phone after having to comfort her, to get to sleep. I feel sick to my stomach. I am now on my knees begging. She is petried.”The mum later told MailOnline: “I thought she was coping so much better. [She was] bottling everything up. When I found this I dont think I have ever cried so much.”Alexandra said she is now so hard-up that she can’t even afford to buy her kids easter eggs.She said: “I went back to my old employer who said he wished he could help me - I truly believe that too - but he told me he could only take me back onI had been made redundant due to Covid-, which I wasnt. I will never forget that moment.“In all honesty, I dont want benefits. I have never claimed in my le. I dont want to start now. I just want my job back”.A government spokesperson said it is up to inidual firmsthey want to pay an employee furlough pay.They explained: “The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme is aimed at those who would otherwise be unemployed as a result of coronavirus.“It allows for those who were on the payroll of a company on  February but subsequently left to be put back on payroll and furloughed.“Decisions around whether to offer to furlough someone are down to the inidual company.”

title: mps extra cash expenses work home coronavirus
story: The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority has issued updated guidance which states every MP can access the additional cash to boost their office budget to pay for things like laptops for staff and electricity.In addition, the monthly credit limit for MPs has been increased to £,, a  day limit on expenses claims has been suspended and rules on the evidence needed for costs to be reimbursed have been relaxed.The move by the expenses watchdog has been described as crude by critics amid concerns that the updated system and extra cash could be open to abuse.Sir Alistair Graham, a former chairman of the committee on standards in public le, hit out at the decision and said: It seems to me a very crude approach.I think the public may be slightly puzzled as to why what looks like a generous payment of this nature has been made without first doing a bit more research into what the actual costs are.And James Roberts, political director of the Taxpayers Alliance, said: While its reasonable for MPs staff to have access to the equipment they need to work from home during this crisis, politicians should take care to use the cash properly and avoid it being seen as a personal equipment slush fund.But parliamentary staffers hit back at the criticism, saying it enabled them to work from home during the crisis.Alice Hopkin, a Conservative Parliamentary worker tweeted: “MPs  staff based in Westminster need Parliament IT equipment to be able to do their work securely from home.”She added that “not a penny will go to MPs” but the backlash was filling staffers inboxes with “ill informed emails distracting us from emergency casework.”She added: “My bosses  colleagues are working round the clock everyday to help s of constituents getting in touch.“The people who are furious that we can work securely at home will also expect immediate helpthey asked.”The guidance, published last month, reads: This is an uncertain and challenging time. Ipsa is committed to supporting MPs and their staff to carry on with their work as far as possible.In a letter to MPs, Richard Lloyd, the interim chairman of Ipsa, wrote: We have agreed a series of immediate measures that we hope will provide you with the resources and flexibility to concentrate on your parliamentary duties and support your staff.Minister James Cleverly added after the story that he would like to publicly thank my teamfor the work that they are doing.I know they aren’t the only ones having a tough time but we MPs couldn’t help our constituents properly without them.They are helping and working with worried, often vulnerable people on my behalf, who are themselves dealing with unprecedented situations. They are researching, collating, and passing on advice and guidance in a fast changing environment.The volume of work has, understandably, increased over the last few weeks and they are working through it with all the additional challenges of working remotely.If things are a bit slower than usual, please bear with us as we navigate these uncharted waters. So to my team I say “thank you”.Labour staffer Amelia-Rose Tighe added: I’ve had to procure secure laptops for staff to work at home.We have never had as many vulnerable people contact us needing help.Anyone bashing this- are you expecting staff to travel to work to help constituents or should we just ignore them This money does NOT go in MPs pockets as the headline suggests, it goes into a budget to be spent on running an office. title: giant asian hornets find nest get rid
story: With the insects being a bother to many Brits and the environment during the season, here is what to do when you spot them.The giant Asian hornet is the largest in the world and is native to south-east Asia.Often, they are confused with European hornets, as they are similar in appearance.They arrived in the UK in  after France was accidentally exposed to them in .A single sting from them could be fatal to people who are allergic to their venom.Multiple stings at one time to any human can also be fatal.Asian hornets are not only a bother to terried humans, experts have recently warned that they can cost the UK up to £.million in environmental damages every year.The government has said it is keen to stop the spread of the insects because of the risks they pose to honeybees and the environment.If you spot an Asian hornet, do not run as they are fast flyers and are provoked by moving targets.You must not disturb or approach giant hornets or their nest as this can be seen as a sign of provocation.The government has advised they must be reportedspotted using the Asian Hornet Watch App available on Apple and android.Also, you can help get rid of them by filling out an online report form or by emailing alertnonnative@ceh.ac.uk.After confirmation, experts will work to get rid of them.Being able to spot an Asian Hornets nest is vital.This looks very similar to a wasp nest and starts off about the size of a tennis ball and grows throughout the spring summer, according to the British Beekeepers Association.It may be found be in garages, sheds, wood stores and sides of building etc.It is essential not to approach or try to handle a nest as this can trigger a group attack which can be fatal.If you find a nest, don’t try to remove it yourself – it can be dangerous and should only be done by experts.When a sighting is confirmed, experts from the National Bee Unit NBU and the Animal and Plant Health Agency APHA will work quickly to find and destroy any active nests in the area, according to a government statement.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: home secretary priti patel blasts top cop snoop shopping coronavirus lockdown
story: Priti, , made the comments while speaking to The Sun’s Executive Editor Dan Wootton on his talkRADIO Drivetime show this afternoon.She came on air just minutes after leaving today’s emergency Cobra meeting and gave her first and only interview since the lockdown began.When asked about the comments made by Northamptonshire’s Chief Constable Nick Adderley in a press conference, where he warned the public officers would stop and search their trolleysthey failed to adhere to the current lockdown measures, she said:  “That is not appropriate, let me be clear about that.“I work with the police and leadership every day of the week and have been since this crisis and leading up to this crisis“That is not the guidance or the measures we have been adopting thus far.”She went on to ask the public to adhere to the lockdown over the Easter weekend and praised the public for their reaction to measures put in place by the government so far.Priti said: “I think what we should say about this weekend in particular, the weather is going to be good, it is Easter. We all need to take responsibility here. This is not about overreach.“We had scurrilous stories a few weeks ago about officers snooping through baskets and removing Easter eggs and that became a trading standards issue.“That is not what the police are there to do. As I said the police are there for public order.“I will be very candid, not everyone will get this right. It will take a few weeks to have these measures bed in.“We want our public spaces to be respected and utilised in the right way.“This is not about heavy handed law enforcement. I pay credit to the police, and the majority of the British public – these are extraordinary times.“But the fact of the matter is,you’re having a party or having a mass gathering do not be surprisedthe police come up and ask you to stop.“The police are using a common sense approach. Enforcement will always be used as a last resort.”In her interview Priti went on to accuse Yvette Cooper of playing politics and insisted she had given the Labour MP a date to appear in front of the Home Affairs Select Committee.When askedshe was concernedYvette wanted to publicly quiz her over bullying allegations made before the start of the crisis, and whether she wanted to deny those on the record, Priti answered: “This is not what this is about at all.“I have offered the chair of the committee regular briefings throughout this pandemic, including access to classied material.“It is disappointing to see this at the time of the crisis when I have already offered a date. There is politicking going on.“When you look at the work of the Home Office during this pandemic, by making  calls free of charge, through the extension of NHS visas, to ious things we’ve been doing across fraud, cyber, national security, policing every single day and the help we are giving to the front line – a lot of that is self evident.“I quite frankly think it is politicking, when we have given access to the entire committee to the department, to myself in terms of another date.“I just think it’s politics basically.”Priti also went on to give up an update about Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who on Thursday night was moved to a ward after spending three nights in intensive care at St Thomas Hospital in London.She said: “He is doing well from what we’re hearing, but we should take great heart that he is in the care of the NHS. We are rooting for him. He is really great, we just want him to get well now.”“I spoke to him last week, around the last cabinet meeting and then it was clear he was unwell and that he needed rest and recoup.“He has been working flat out leading us through this, we need to give him the time and space to recover. We wish him well.”During the interview Priti went on to say the government were considering new measures to help domestic violence victims and confirmed she would be laying out the plans next week.She said of domestic abuse victims on lockdown with their partners: “This is an absolute priority for the police.“I have spent a lot of time speaking to charities and third parties and also the victims commissioner.“There is a lot of work taking place, I have already been resourcing this area. But of course the longer the pandemic continues there will be all sorts of issues around people staying at home and victims of abuse being with their perpetrators. We are finding other ways we can give them the support but also ways we can do more in prevention and protection.“I have been doing a lot of work with this sector and charities about how we can improve our response and get resources out there on the front line in dferent ways. I will be outlining these in the days to come but I can assure you that when it comes to vulnerable children and domestic abuse victims there is a lot of cross government work taking place.”Priti also discussed the increased threats to the public from online fraudsters since the beginning of the pandemic.She said: “I spend every day looking at threats and risks to homeland security. We are seeing all sorts of things but we are especially seeing new threats from online harms and threats in terms of cyber fraud and breaches of cyber security.“As a result there are more protective measures we are undertaking. For example we are seeing a lot more financial fraud online. We are seeing more activity in the space and sphere on online harms particularly around vulnerable people and children and I am working with the National Crime Agency on this right now.“The wrong types of people, perpetrators of crime are at home and are spending a lot of time on the internet, so a lot of work is taking place across the whole of law enforcement, the crime agency, our security and intelligence services as well.“We absolutely are on it.“I will be very candid, they themselves are facing challenges themselves in terms of how they are working.“Across the policing and intelligence community they are incredible in what they are doing but the intelligence they are being fed in – we are actually seeing less crime but they are actually dealing with more crime because they are able to see more crime, perhaps in a way in which they haven’t been able to previously.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china dogs companions new guidelines animal trade
story: The announcement by the Ministry of Agriculture was described as a potential game changer in animal welfare.Even though dog meat remains a delicacy in many Chinese regions, the notice published yesterday made it clear that hounds would no longer be considered as livestock.The notice by the agriculture ministry said: As far as dogs are concerned, along with the progress of human civilisation and the public concern and love for animal protection, dogs have been specialised to become companion animals, and internationally are not considered to be livestock, and they will not be regulated as livestock in China.The word livestock is used to refer to a category of animals that can be bred to provide food, milk, fur, fibre and medicine or to serve the needs of sports or the military.The new coronavirus, which is believed to have originated from horseshoe bats, put a spotlight on Chinas wild animal trade.COVID- - which was first identied in the Chinese city of Wuhan - could have been passed onto humans by intermediary species on sale at a wet market.Those markets, where wild and often poached animals are packed together, have been described as a breeding ground for disease and an incubator for a multitude of viruses to evolve.Following the outbreak of the virus, China banned the breeding, trading and consumption of wildle - revoking all existing licenses.It also promised to revise legislation to make the ban permanent.The draft guidelines published yesterday - which have been opened to the public for consultation - listed  traditional livestock species, including cattle, pigs, poultry and camels.The notice also added  special species that would also be exempt from wild animal trading restrictions, including reindeer, alpaca, pheasants, ostriches and foxes.Dog consumption has become increasingly unpopular in China and the southern city of Shenzhen became the first to ban it last month.However, the Humane Society International, an animal welfare group, estimated that around  million dogs a year are still killed in China for meat, including stolen pets.The city of Yulin in the region of Guangxi holds an annual dog meat festival in June.There, stray dogs or stolen pet dogs are trapped in tiny cages where they cannot breathe or even stand up properly.The animals are then transported to a slaughterhouse in Yulin, south-west China.Charity Humane Society International has said that as many as  dogs are killed at the abattoir every day.Wendy Higgins, a Humane Society International spokeswoman, said: This draft proposal could signal a game-changer moment for animal protection in China.

title: change health conditions lockdown twice
story: A NEW change in lockdown rules means people with certain health conditions can now leave home twice a day.It comes after a legal discussion between Public Health England and a firm representing two autistic children who need to leave twice for their health.Now those with health conditions which require them to leave home more than once a day will be allowed to do so.The updated guidance now reads: You can leave your home for medical need.If youhave a specic health condition that requires you to leave the home to maintain your health - includingthat involves travel beyond your local area - then you can do so.This could, for example, include where iniduals with learning disabilities or autism require specic exercise in an open space two or three times each day - ideally in line with a care plan agreed with a medical professional.Before the change Brits were only allowed to leave their homes once a day and not allowed to travel signicant distances.People are only allowed to leave their home for the following very limited purposes:It comes after Birdmans LLP law firm was asked to help by two families with children on the autistic spectrum.The firm explained: One child in particular is deliberately taken to a quiet location that is not local to them, because of their particular needs and where there is a far more limited risk of infectionthanhe were to remain in an urban environment.It was submitted that adults and children with certain health conditionswere disproportionately impacted by the inflexible policy which required everyone to only leave the house for exercise once per day, and which was therefore unlawful and discriminatory.After the change, a spokesperson for the Cabinet Office said: “The single most important action we can all take, in fighting coronavirus, is to stay at home in order to save lives, protect the vulnerable and protect the NHS.“We understand that this will be more dficult for some, that’s why we claried the guidance regarding the needs of those with specic health conditions such as learning disabilities or autism.It comes as police called for further lockdown powers.At least five chief constables support bans on long car journeys and outdoor exercise as they gear up for a sunny Easter weekend.They are urging ministers to give them the powers they need to keep lockdown enforced over Easter.People have been ignoring social distancing rules and flocking to parks and beaches across the country as the weather warms up.Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned last weekend restrictions would have to be tightened  people continued to ignore the lockdown.A Government evaluation of lockdown powers in England is considering tougher restrictions such as those in force in Wales - including restricting exercise to once a day.Before falling ill, Boris Johnson pledged to review the lockdown on Easter Monday, April  — three weeks after it began on March .But Downing Street is seriously concerned that people may defy advice and head out to enjoy the C bank holiday sunshine.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: uk lockdown dominic raab too early
story: IT IS too early to lt the coronvirus lockdown measures right now and Brits must stay home this Easter bank holiday weekend, Dominic Raab said tonight.The Foreign Secretary, who is standing in for Boris while hes in hospital, apologised to the nation that they will be unable to see their families this weekend as part of the fight to stop the virus.And he took the chance to thank everyone - including NHS staff on the front line - for their hard work so far in savings lives.He told the public ahead of a sunny weekend: It is too early to lt the measures we have put in place.We must stick to the plan and continue to be guided by the science.Thank you for your sacrice but we are not done yet. We must keep going.No easing of the lockdown will happen until at least the end of next week, he said - but the strict measures will likely continue for even longer.Professor Chris Whitty said he would expect the number of deaths to continue rising for at least two weeks past when the number of people in intensive care starts to flatten off, showing the peak is still some time away.Mr Raab urged anyone considering breaking the rules in the coming days to think very hard about those who were on the front line battling the virus.He would usually be spending the Easter bank holiday weekend with his family but admitted we just cant do those sorts of things, and I am really sorry about that.As a country we need to be united in this mission.We have to keep it up.Mr Raab admitted tonight that he hasnt spoken to Boris Johnson since he went into hospital, and was rushed into intensive care on Monday evening.He said it was important to give him time to rest and recover, and stressed I’ve got all the authority I need to make the relevant decisions.That will include huge choices on extending the lockdown next week,the PM isnt well enough by then.The news came as:The Government is continuing to gather all the data on how the lockdown is working so far before making any firm calls, he said.The early signs suggest that they are having an impact, but its too early to say that conclusively, he added.We will be guided by the science at all times.We dont expect to be able to say more on this until the end of next week.The measures will have to stay in place until we have the evidence that clearly shows weve moved beyond the peak.Mr Raab said the PM was still in intensive care but continues to make positive steps forward, and he is in good spirits.He is still not in need of a ventilator and is able to breathe without assistance.Boris is said to be sitting up in bed and talking to the NHS staff who are caring for him too.It’s expected that the lockdown will be extended past the three week target in the coming days – because Britain is not yet over the worst of the virus.Speaking this morning, Scottish First Minister Sturgeon said: “I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately, or even imminently.Extensive work is being done across Whitehall on the Government’s exit strategy, but they have yet to spell out any detail or say when the public might see a plan.No say the focus now needs to be on stopping the spread of the virus and increasing capacity in the NHS to save lives.London Mayor Sadiq story: Others were spotted sunbathing topless and enjoying barbecues on the beach.It comes as forces across the UK are preparing to ramp up enforcement of coronavirus regulations with tomorrow set to be the hottest Good Friday ever.In a blatant breach of the lockdown rules, a group of teens were spotted inhaling balloons in Hampstead Heath, in North London, this afternoon.One onlooker told the Sun Online: They were in a group of around five or six. They were sat drinking from plastic bottles and inhaling balloons.They were clearly ignoring the lockdown rules.Brits were also snapped soaking up the sun on Brighton Beach today, while police ordered a couple to put out their barbecue.As the country heads into the Easter bank holiday weekend, No  said it is at a critical juncture in the battle to curb the spread of the deadly virus.The Prime Ministers official spokesman made clear there can be no early lting of the strict social distancing rules, urging the public to stick with it.Tourist hotspots have said holidaymakers and second homeowners are not welcome during the Easter weekend, as they urged visitors to stay at home.Northamptonshire Chief Constable Nick Adderley said his force was only a few days away from imposing road blocks and searching shopping trolleys for non-essential itemspeople continued to flout the rules.If things dont improve, and we dont get the compliance we would expect, then the next stage will be road blocks and it will be stopping people to ask why they are going, where theyre going, he said.This is about reasonableness andpeople are not reasonable in terms of the journeys and the trips they are taking, they are going to fall foul of the law.Cheshire police said there were plans for patrols on major roads, with officers stopping drivers to check whether their travel was essential, while Avon and Somerset said they would have more police on the roads.Meanwhile, Greater Manchester Police revealed they had to break up a staggering  parties last weekend – some with DJs, fireworks and bouncy castles.There were , coronavirus-related breaches reported between Saturday and Tuesday, the force said.The Government is due to carry out the first three-week review of the restrictions introduced last month early next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: By comparison there have been about , cases in Spain and , in Italy, according to researchers at Johns Hopkins.The US leads the way with , cases - which is now about one third of the total cases worldwide.It was revealed Thursday that the number of deaths in the Empire State rose by .Additionally, it was announced that NYC correction officers will be tested after nearly  contracted the virus.The latest disturbing numbers came as New York Gov. We look at the data every day.I’m telling you, the smartest person will start by saying I don’t know and that is to me the sign of wisdom.Cuomo confirmed over , New Yorkers had died from coronavirus versus the , deaths that resulted in the September  terror attacks.He also revealed the state lost another  people in  hours again on April  after the same amount of patients died the day before.This number marked the biggest single-day death toll from the deadly bug and Cuomo revealed the state had to bring on more funeral directors to cope with the mounting fatalities.The straight-talking governor was asked to comment on de Blasios statement Thursday that social distancing guidelines may have to be tightened in NYC until June.“April, we’re going to have to fight this fight the way we are now into May, that could be a lot of May in fact, de Blasio said.I would love itsome change could happen in May. But it may not be until June.The news comes  days after the PAUSE measure was put into effect, shuttering business and schools around New York.Cuomo pointed out that although its been  days since the first COVID case emerged in NY - and  days since was detected in the US - the state wasnt out of the woods yet.He cautioned residents who were too eager to end this groundhog day reality.Yeah, you’re not out of the woods yet and now is not the time to misunderstand what’s happening, Cuomo said of the decreasing hospitalization rates in-state. Later, de Blasio appeared to double down on his hopeful projection, saying he didnt want to overstate the positive developments in NYC.Theyre good signs but theyre early signs, he told Andrea Mitchell. title: inside worlds last cannibal tribes human flesh rituals
story: The tribes exist in some of the remotest corners of the world, and can be seen living as they have done for thousands of years.The Aghori monks of India use herbal drugs, alcohol, and meditation as well as human flesh in their rituals.The group reportedly obtain corpses from the Ganges River, downstream from where they are set afloat by relatives unable to afford a cremation or burial.In , US broadcast Reza Aslan met the a number of the monks and was filmed eating human brain while taking part in a ritual.Freelance photographer Tamara Merino, who also spent time with the group, said: “They are people that have so much love and respect for people, animals and nature.It’s just as beautul as any other religion is.”The Asmat people are native to New Guinea Island, and are thought to have traditionally hunted their enemies and used their skulls in cooking.Journalist Carl Hoffman wrote of the group: “They shook the brains out onto the leaf of a palm, scraped inside the skull with a kne to get every last bite, then mixed the mass with sago, wrapped the leaf up, and roasted it on the fire.The group is thought to have been responsible for the  death of Michael Rockefeller, a member of the Rockefeller dynasty and fth son of future vice president Nelson Rockefeller.Rockefeller was on an expedition in the New Guinea region when the boat in which he was travelling capsized.He left a companion drting with the boat and swam  miles to shore, but is thought to have been killed by the Asmat after he arrived.The Korowai are a tribe that live in West Papau in the western half of New Guinea Island.They live mostly in dense areas of rainforest, and remain isolated from much of modern world.Italian photojournalist Gianlunca Chiodini said of several days he spent with the group: “I really wanted to visit one of the most genuine and remote tribes in the world.“The Korowai live in the heart of the rainforest, where they’re not yet exposed to the modern world, so they still maintain many of their age-old traditions.”The group reportedly continue to practice witchcraft and to eat human flesh, though has been speculation that members have encouraged the stories to promote interest from the outside world.The Sentinelese are a tribe that live on North Sentinel, an island off the eastern coast of India, and are among the last truly uncontacted people in the world.They speak a unique language and have had very limited contact with the outside world.They have been described as a Stone Age tribe, and are believed to have lived on the island in isolation for up to , years.In , the group killed US missionary John Allen Chau with bows and arrows after he landed on the island as part of an attempt to convert its inhabitants to Christianity.Speaking at the time about planned attempt to recover Chaus body, Survival Internationals Director Stephen Corry said: The risk [to the Sentinelese] of a deadly epidemic of flu, measles, or other outside disease is very real, and increases with every contact.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: A LAND army of Brits is needed to pick our crops to stop £billion worth of produce going to waste.Farmers are missing , fruit pickers and factory staff as foreign seasonal workers are banned in the coronavirus crisis.Experts warned the UK is facing a potential disaster with as much as .million tons of produce set to be dumped.Unless the country can mobilise to “pick for victory” we are ­facing losing million apples, .million pears, .million plums and million cherries.Up to .billion raspberries, billion strawberries and .billion blackcurrants could also go.The closure of chip shops due to the coronavirus lockdown has created a surplus of , tons of potatoes worth £.million.Rhubarb farmer Janet Oldroyd-Hulme, of West Yorks, said: “We won’t need our foreign workersthe English, Scottish, Irish and Welsh all look to their local farms to help there.”“Otherwise there will be fruit and vegetables that will rot.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.The Government has said furloughed workers are free to sign up for land work — and urged them to find recruiting agencies.Environment Secretary George Eustice said: “We need to mobilise the British workforce.”“I would encourage as many people as possible to sign up.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: THE Queen broke with tradition and sent her annual Maundy Money to pensioners by post because of coronavirus.She traditionally hands it out at her Maundy Thursday service at St George’s Chapel, Windsor Castle.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal But the lockdown meant the event was cancelled for the first time in her -year reign as she self-isolated.Instead, she sent commemorative coins to  pensioners rewarded for their good work in the community.They included -year-old World War Two hero Bill Allen, of Leyton, East London, and the world’s oldest bellringer, Thomas Brock, , of Sunbury-on-Thames, West London.In a letter, the Queen wrote: “This ancient Christian ceremony, which reflects Jesus’ instruction to his Disciples to love one another, is a call to the service of others, something that has been at the centre of my le. I believe it is a call to service for all of us.“It is one of my most rewarding duties as Sovereign to observe this highly signicant ceremony at such an important point in the Christian calendar.”The money included a £ coin marking  years since poet William Wordsworth’s birth and a p coin celebrating the  Olympics.They also received  freshly minted silver coins.Another recipient was Jane Armstrong, who runs youth clubs, crisis centres and food banks at her church in Bishop Auckland, Co Durham.She said: “I’m disappointed but the ceremony couldn’t go ahead in the current situation.”But Jane , added: “It was a wonderful surprise to get themthrough the post.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: louisiana dad disfigured burns pouring gasoline barbecue
story: Charles Dittler felt like he was burning alive during the accident, which left him in a medically induced coma for two weeks.The dad-of-one suffered third-degree burns to his face, arms and torso in the January  incident,reported.Charles, of Shevreport, Louisiana, told the news outlet: I was at my ex-girlfriend’s house with some friends and we were hanging out around a fire in the backyard.The fire was dying out and I had filled up a can of diesel earlier that day so wanted to use it to liven up the fire.But I picked up a can full of gas instead and I had no idea it was not diesel.He said there was no time to react once he starting pouring and recalled the gas blowing up in his hand, exploding, and pushing him to the ground.I started rolling around and screaming I’m on fire someone put me out! It felt like my body was burning from the inside.I thought I was going to die there and then. I was burning alive, Charles explained.His ex-girlfriends dad, Darry Wright, came to Charles rescue with a fire extinguisher.Charles, who happened to be wearing fire-retardant work pants, was on fire for approximately  seconds, according to .He saved my le and I owe him a lot, Charles said of Darry.Immediately after the accident, he was airlted to Ochsner Medical Centre, Louisiana.Charles had to undergo physiotherapy and  surgeries, including multiple skin grafts and reconstructive work.Doctors used skin from his thigh and shoulder to repair his eyelids and neck.The also reconstructed his chin with arteries and tissue from his arm.A GoFundMe, created two years ago to help with Charles rehab and personal bills, has since raised nearly ,.My brother’s physical appearance was changed forever that day, the fundraisers organizer, Brandon Edwards wrote.Despite his altered looks, Charles is proud of who hes become.I want to use my experience to give other people hope and to ask other people to accept who they are.In a way I am glad it happened because it means I can have a positive impact on other people and make a dference, Charles told .He now talks on a local radio station for Motivational Mondays and aspires to visit schools in the future to discuss fire safety.Charles has also designed Pain to Purpose T-shirts, which he sells online and recommends others to weartheyve experienced pain in the past.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams is shutting  of its stores this month, as it continues its massive programme of shop closures.At the end of , it was revealed that Debenhams was set to close  of its stores.But  stores have been confirmed to shut in the next three weeks, including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Heres the full list of closures announced so far:Its believed to be a combination of increasing rents, business rates and a rise in online shopping.Richard Lim of Retail Economics, told the BBC in October  that Debenhams is operating in the part of the market under the most intense amount of pressure.He said: Put simply, department stores are incredibly expensive to run.The combination of too much space, inflexible leases and spiralling operating costs are set against a backdrop an accelerating behavioural sht towards online and experiences.This is eroding their profitability and changes in the business need to occur at a pacethey are to survive.Speaking at the time, Debenhams executive chairman Terry Duddy said: Debenhams has a clear strategy and a bright future, but in order for the business to prosper, we need to restructure the groups store portfolio and its balance sheet, which are not appropriate for todays much changed retail environment.Our priority is to save as many stores and as many jobs as we can, while making the business fit for the future.The retailer, which employs , staff, is now in the hand of lenders as part of this process.They took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.It would have seen Debenhams lenders agree to write off £million of its £million debts, which the retailer said was not sufficient.Instead, it has chosen to implement a pre-pack administrationThis is an insolvency process for a business to sell its assets before appointing administrations.It is a powerful way of selling on a business to a third part of buyer.The deal doesnt mean that Debenhams will disappear from the high street but some stores will still close.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards as stores will continue to trade as normal.However shoppers have been urged to use any gt cards they have while the retailer is still accepting them.Gt cards, orders and s are still being accepted as usual.MoneySavingExpert founder Martin Lewis warned shoppers not to buy any new gt cards from the retailer.He said: Clearly, Debenhams is not in the most stable state at the moment. So personally I wouldnt be buying anyone any gt vouchers from there in the future.Mr Lewis also says shoppers should be careful about what they order or buy from the retailer and recommends they make purchases on card so theyre protectedsomething goes wrong.

story: NewsCoronavirus: Pressure on Priti Patel after Home Office staff told toto workThe Home Secretary faces questions after Passport Office workers were reportedly told Covid- will infect % of people and we cant hide away from it foreverShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. More than  Labour MPs joined together asking the government to forgive student loans for nurses fast-tracked to the frontline.Some , students from  universities had signed up for paid placements as of Friday, according to Health Education England figures. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UKaposs coronavirus lockdown looks set to be extended as Brits hunker down for the long haul. Drastic limits on leaving your home will be reviewed by April  - but itaposs clear they wonapost be lted. As coronavirus deaths continue to rocket, they will probably drt on into May at least. A meeting of the COBRA emergency committee today kicked off the process of working out what to do next, chaired by Boris Johnsonaposs deputy Dominic Raab. But the government isnapost planning to actually tighten the law - yet. Instead the focus will be on enforcing the law we already have and making it last longer.  Meanwhile police are preparing for a tough Easter weekend - with threats to search peopleaposs shopping and fine anyone going to bask in the sun. So what can and canapost you do under the lockdown law, what is changing, and when will it all end   Hereaposs the lockdown latest explained. What are the basic lockdown rules  You cannot leave the house where you live without reasonable excuse. That boils down to:Shopping for basic necessities, for example food and medicine, which must be as infrequent as possible One form of exercise a day, for example a run, walk, or cycle - alone or with members of your household Any medical need, including to donate blood, avoid or escape risk of injury or harm, or to provide care or to help a vulnerable person Travelling for work purposes, but only where you cannot work from home. Gatherings of more than two people are banned in public - unless youaposre from the same household, or a few other exceptions . And pubs, cafes, restaurants, gyms, funfairs, playgrounds, sports courts, cinemas, theatres, nightclubs, bingo halls, concert halls, museums, galleries, car showrooms, casinos, betting shops, spas, hair and beauty salons, barbers, massage parlours, tattoo studios, skating rinks and more must shut.  What is the punishment for breaking the lockdown  Breaking the rules above without reasonable excuse, or obstructing an officer enforcing them, is a criminal offence and you can be prosecuted. However, you can in most cases avoid a criminal conviction by paying a aposfixed penalty noticeapos issued by the police within  days. The law allows police to issue £ fixed penalty notices - rising to £ for a second offence and then doubling each time up to a cap of £. Police, PCSOs, council officers and other government representatives can also order or force you toto your home, and disperse gatherings of more than two people.  When did the UK go into lockdown - and for how long  The lockdown was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday  March. It took effect immediately. Police powers to enforce the lockdown took force a few days later - at pm on Thursday  March. The law says the lockdown must be reviewed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock every three weeks, with the first review by Thursday  April. But reviewing the lockdown doesnapost mean it stops. The law is in force for up to six months without the government needing to write a new one. Will the lockdown be extended for longer than three weeks  Yes. The UK government hasnapost made an official announcement because thataposll only come next week. But ministers, civil servants and  Downing Street have been absolutely clear that April  is much too soon to end the lockdown. Wales has already confirmed it will extend the lockdown. Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon added: I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately or even imminently. Even before a COBRA meeting to discuss the lockdown, Downing Street basically confirmed the UK government agrees with Ms Sturgeon.  Why isnapost the extension being announced properly today  Because the government wants to wait to see how well the restrictions are working at reducing cases. A formal announcement will be made on or before April , based on scientic evidence. Whoaposll make the decision  Technically itaposs made by Health Secretary Matt Hancock but itaposll be overseen by Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in, Dominic Raab. Not the PM, whoaposs in intensive care. Downing Street said: The Prime Minister is not working. I think weaposre very clear on that. And he has asked the First Secretary of State to deputise for him. It will be the First Secretary of State who leads the COBRA meeting [on Thursday] and the First Secretary of State who will lead any cabinet decision making process.  So can I go out for a picnic this Easter weekend then  No, absolutely not. Yes, the lockdown is being reviewed, but that absolutely does not mean it has stopped. You may only go outside your home with a reasonable excuse - just like any other day under lockdown. When will the lockdown end  We donapost know. But it will only be lted when the UK is well over the peak of new Covid- cases per day, and thataposs not any time soon. Ministers had hoped the peak would be Easter Sunday but estimates now put it at least a week or two later. Even then, cases have to drastically dwindle too. Otherwise thereaposll just be a second outbreak. The UK government has also repeatedly refused to say what its aposexitapos strategy is. Until we get a vaccine next year, itaposs quite possible they just donapost know yet. Officials havenapost ruled out a partial end to the lockdown, where some people can go outside earlier than others. Or restrictions being lted for a few weeks, then reimposed.  Are even stricter restrictions on the way  Not right now, no. The government hasnapost ruled out making the rules even stricter - such as banning exercise. But No emphasised the focus is on policing the current rules more strictly, not making new ones. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: I think the focus for now is ensuring that people continue to stick by the measures weaposve put in place. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden warned the government may enhance or change the lockdown, but thataposs not happening right now. No said: Weaposve always said thatthe scientic advice suggested other steps are needed weaposd be prepared to take them. But for now our focus is on ensuring the steps we already have in place are properly enforced. What does the law actually say  The lockdown is enforced through a law called the Health Protection Regulations . Importantly, it isnapost exactly the same as the government guidance. You should of course follow both, but it makes a dference to whether police can stop you going about your business. Here we go through a few common situations. Whataposs the full list of aposreasonable excusesapos for leaving my house  Reasonable excuses include, but it appears are not limited to:To obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies for those in the same householdor for vulnerable persons To take exercise either alone or with other members of their household To seek medical assistance To provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person, or to provide emergency assistance To donate blood To travel for the purposes of work or to provide voluntary or charitable services, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home To attend a funeral of a member of the person’s household, a close family member, orneither are attending, a friend To fulfil a legal obligation, including attending court or satisfying bail conditions To access critical public services, including childcare school, social services, DWP services, victims of crime services To allow children with shared custody to move between each parentaposs house For a minister of religion, to go to their place of worship To move house where reasonably necessary To avoid injury or illness or to escape a risk of harm.When can more than two people gather in public  Exceptions to the rule are:Where all the people in the gathering are members of the same household Where the gathering is essential for work purposes To attend a funeral To facilitate a house move* To provide emergency assistance* To fulfil a legal obligation* To provide care to a vulnerable person** Where reasonably necessary. Can police fine meI exercise twice in one day  No. Government guidance is clear - you should only exercise once a day. You should follow this advice. But the law itself doesnapost specy how many times you can go out. It just says you may take exerciseyou need to. Meanwhile, guidance has been updated to let people with a medical need go out multiple times a day, for instance people with learning disabilities or autism.  Can police stop me sitting in the park  Yes,you canapost provide a reasonable excuse. You wonapost be surprised to hear the list of possible reasonable excuses does not include sitting, having a picnic or sunbathing - evenyouaposre doing it with proper social distancing. Police have of course been asked to show discretion, and there are exceptions in the rules for people with a medical need. Can police go through my shopping  The law isnapost % clear - but the Home Secretary has said itaposs not appropriate. It comes after a police force threatened to go through peopleaposs bags to check for non-essential items. After an outcry, Northamptonshire Police later claried: We absolutely will NOT be searching peopleaposs shopping trolleys in Northamptonshire. Home Secretary Priti Patel later said this is not appropriate and branded it heavy-handed. So thataposs all good. But what does the law say  The law says you can go out to buy basic necessities, including food and medical supplies. So you might interpret that asyou start buying non-essential items, youaposre breaking the law. But the government also says open shops donapost have to pull all their non-essential items from stock. So Sainsburyaposs can carry on selling, say, kidsapos toys and paddling pools - and thereaposs nothing to stop you buying them. Shops that are still open are free to sell any items that they have in stock, Downing Street told us. Yet Downing Street also told us: When we ask the police to carry out enforcement of any rules we give them discretion on how to do that. Thataposs the nature of policing in the UK. They have set out in guidance to officers that they should engage, explain, encourage and then finally enforce.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Coronavirus and lack of PPE has turned care homes into death trapsThe battle against the Covid- pandemic in the UK is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeriesShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionSeven residents of Hawthorn Green home in Stepney - which houses  people - have died since the pandemic started " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe priority in fighting the coronavirus has been to make sure the NHS has the equipment and resources it needs. Everyone understands the importance of supporting doctors, nurses and other staff on the frontline. That is why you came out in your millions again last night to applaud our  brilliant national health service. But the battle against the pandemic is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeries. In the scramble to shore up the NHS, the Government appears to have neglected the half a million people in care homes. These residents are almost exclusively in the high-risk category. Yet care home operators say they have been ignored and are struggling to get the help they need. Many are short of staff because workers have had to go into self-isolation. Others desperately want personal protection equipment such as face masks and gloves. One home in Luton has reported that  of its residents have died and tragically there are more cases emerging across the country. Without urgent action more lives will be lost. We cannot allow these homes, offering comfort and support, to turn into death traps. Break traditionThe Easter break is traditionally a time for worship and for friends and familiesto come together.A time when children enjoy Easter Egg hunts and many head for the country or coast. With good weather in many parts, the temptation to break the lockdown restrictions will be strong. But we urge you to stay home.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum has given a harrowing account of the final visit she and her children made to their dad as he lies dying in hospital with coronavirus. Cardf mum Sue Martin spoke to the BBCaposs Today programme about the fateful call from doctors telling her that her husband was being put on a ventilator, and the shell-shocked family needed to say goodbye.Sue described her -year-old husband Mal Martin as fit and healthy. But the devastated family has been told he has aposzero chanceapos of survival. The mum gave an emotional interview recounting the familyaposs final phone call, and a ten-minute visit behind screens around Malaposs hospital bed. Her description of the moment she and the coupleaposs two children, aged  and , stood behind screens around a sleeping Malaposs bedside to say their goodbyes moved listeners to tears. The family was allowed to go into hospital in full protective wear for what is likely to be the last time they are all together. Malaposs we and children could not even touch him to say farewell as they stood around his bedside at the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend. Sue recalled: We just told him that we loved him. It was heartbreaking to hear the children tell him that they were going to make him proud. The family have been left to prepare for the beloved husband and fatheraposs death as he lies in intensive care on the brink of organ failure. Despite being told there was no way he would pull through, Sue says the family is living in hope of a miracle.According to the Independent, Mal is chairman of a recruitment firm and Sue is a communications manager at the Department for Transport, and the couple have been together for  years.Mal has Type  diabetes and had suffered a heart attack four years ago, but had lived a very, very healthy le, his we told the Today programme.   Sue said Mal first began feeling unwell with cold-like symptoms on March , and his condition got progressively worse. After about a week, his condition declined so badly he could not get out of bed. Sue told the Independent Mal had a persistent cough, a headache and a temperature of .C. She added in the BBC interview: The cough was the worse thing for him. It was like nothing  Iaposve heard before. aposI wish we had been able to give him a hugapos Mal began self-isolating to keep the rest of his family safe as soon as he began feeling unwell. But when his condition did not improve after another week, Sue said she tried to seek medical advice. However she claimed she struggled to get through on attempts to call NHS  services, saying she kept being put on hold for more than an hour each time then was cut off. She then rang a doctor at the local surgery, who encouraged her to keep a record of Malaposs symptoms and check on him every second hour throughout the days.  But Malaposs symptoms went into sharp decline on March  and Sue said she stayed up all night anxiously checking his condition. At this stage his breathing rate was normal, and the doctor seemed satisfied by his condition and recommended he stay at home at that point. By the early hours of Sunday morning, ten days after he first began showing symptoms of coronavirus his condition was so poor, Sue called an ambulance. She described how his breathing had become rapid, and when the paramedics arrived she and the children were not allowed to go near him. As he was rushed to hospital, they had to say their goodbyes there and then, Sue recalled. She said: It was awful because I wish now that we had been able to give him a hug. She did not know that the worst was yet to come, explaining that the family believed once Mal was admitted to hospital his condition would improve. Sue said: I really thought that a couple of days on oxygen and heaposd be back home with us.  But within around an hour of Malaposs arrival at hospital, she received a call from the AE at the Princess of AE Hospital saying he had whisked straight to intensive careand put on a ventilator. Sue said a doctor told her Mal was very, very sick and the family needed to be prepared that he might not pull through. Sue told Today she never thought her husband would be among the patients fighting for their lives in hospital. She described being shocked to hear that he may not survive, after he had been able to walk out of the family home to a waiting ambulance.  Sue recalled: The nurse said that she had spoken to him and he was aware of what was going to happen to him, and that they were going to put him to sleep and put him on a ventilator to do the breathing for him because his body was very tired and extremely poorly. The last time the family saw each other Sue was surprised to learn that he would soon be unconscious, saying I think I just assumed that a ventilator was like another type of oxygen mask, I didnapost realise it involved him being put to sleep. The nurse told her that Mal had asked for her to call him as he was too upset after he was told he may not ever come off the ventilator. Sue and her children called him over FaceTime, where they saw him struggling to breathe and already wearing an oxygen mask. The family were in tears, realising this might be the last time they were all together again as they were forced to say their goodbyes to Mal.  Sue said: We just told him how much we loved him and I said how much I was really sorry that I hadnapost sent him in earlier... They said in hospital that Iaposd done everything that I could have. He promised he would fight it. She said her husband promised their children he would pull through and be there for him.  He said to my daughter who was , Donapost worry, Iaposm going to be around a while yet and be here for your wedding and for you both growing up and see William play rugby for Wales - heaposs . He was told thathe did recover it would take over a year. Mal texted the family, promising he wouldnapost leave them, Sue said. He said it wasnapost his time, that he missed me too much and that he was coming home. When the text messages ceased, they knew it was because he had been put on the ventilator in ICU. Saying goodbye through a hospital screen She said: That day really was when everything changed for us and we have just been existing since.  She said the hospital had been amazing, with a consultant ringing every day with an update. At first the doctors told the family Mal had   chance of survival. But the -year-old dad is strong, fit and healthy, Sue said. She said the family kept faith when doctors said they would do everything they could to help him. But after a few days on the ventilator, the doctors told her despite their best efforts they had been unable to take him off the ventilator. Then Malaposs kidneys failed, and he was put on dialysis. After that, Sue received the fateful call from the doctors informing the family there was aposalmost zero chanceapos Mal would survive. The doctors told her they were giving him the maximum adrenaline they could to keep the blood pumping to his vital organs. But he was on the brink, and they told Sue they didnapost think they could do anything more for him as it was likely his organs begin failing. Reeling from the news, she rang the hospital again and begged to be able to see her husband. A nurse told Suethe family could get to the hospital quickly, they could have  minutes with Mal and even stayed two hours after her sht to ensure they fulfilled their desperate wish. The nursing sister helped the family dress in full personal protective equipment . Sue said they were taken in to say goodbye to Mal: we werenapost allowed to touch him, but we could speak to him. Essentially we were going in to say our goodbyes. I said to the children... aposyou absolutely donapost have to do this, this is a personal choice, thereaposs no right or wrong. You have to do what you feel.apos But they both wanted very much to come and see him. because they hadnapost been able to really hug him before he left. The family were forced to say their final goodbyes to Mal through screens around his bed. Sue said the medics were wonderful and compassionate.  She recounted the awful scene as she and her children stood around his hospital bed, unable to touch him. It was just like he was asleep. he had so many tubes and obviously wires in him and everything - it was like he was fast asleep. We just told him really that we love him, and it was heartbreaking, really, to hear the childrenthey were going to make him proud. She added: It was very hard not being able to touch him but we were glad to get to see him. aposA little glimmer of hopeapos The family had expected he would not survive Monday, but have since been told his condition has been improved slightly.Doctors said Malaposs lungs and kidneys had failed, but they had noted a slight increase in his blood pressure and were able to reduce his adrenaline .Sue said the family had accepted this did not mean he would survive. She said there had been no improvement or deterioration by Wednesday. He is still extremely, desperately ill and thereaposs still almost zero chance of him pulling through. As the emotional interview came to a close, Sue said the family had not yet given up hope. Although everyday we prepare for the worst, thereaposs a little glimmer of just maybe, just maybe, he might turn a corner. Chances of survival after ventilation slim The latest report into patients admitted into critical care in the UK showed that of those who required ventilation so far, just under a third have survived. Figures for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, from the intensive care national audit , showed that as at Friday, April , of , patients for whom data was available,  had died.  Another  patients were discharged alive from critical care and , patients were last reported as still being in critical care. The NHS requires an estimated , ventilators to meet the demand predicted for the peak of the Covid- pandemic in the UK.

Justine Laymond has a permanently compromised immune system following her le-saving transplant back in  and has one of the worldaposs rarest lung diseases. Speaking to , the -year-old said she knows that catching Covid- would be game over for her, but she is determined to do all she can to stay safe at home. And she is calling on everyone across the UK to do their bit this weekend and asks anyone thinking of breaking the lockdown to simply not do it. She said: The sun may be shining outside - but darkness will fall on others who may die,not yourself. This is not a movie, itaposs reality. Have you got a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Justine was just hours from dying back in July  when she fought back from being in a three-week coma, spending weeks on le support and  lung collapses to be well enough to be put on the transplant list. Her le was eventually saved when she received the healthy lungs of a -year-old man, and she was given another chance at le. But Justine, who is currently furloughed from her part time job at Hyundai in Chelmsford, admits she is frightened for her health once again. But after spending two days crying over what the deadly virus could mean for her, Justine picked herself up and decided to fight for her le - by staying safe and self-isolating. She said: Iaposm so frightened. Iaposm not going out to exercise every day. I need to keep my fitness up so my lungs stay healthy. But I knowI do get it, I will die. I would fight for my leI did get it, but I know it will kill me. Justine, from Rayleigh, Essex added: Iaposve got my wishes written out. If we have to call an ambulance, Iaposve got a list of people to call to say goodbye to. Iaposve got an emergency bag packed. I knowI get this I will die, thataposs the reality.  Justine, who is self-isolating with partner Tom Hipperson, was left in shock when she was not included in the Governmentaposs list of .milllion people most at risk from the virus. Despite being a transplantee, permanently immuno-compromised and having serious underlying health conditions, she did not get a text to say she would have help getting the vital medicines she takes each day, or have any way of getting food. After numerous calls to her GP and hospital, she was eventually told her medical records were not accurate and her medical code needed amending so she could be included on the high risk list.  And now she is back to her positive self, doing fitness classes at home and keeping up her hobbies as a drag queen, where she has a large online presence, and keeping busy with cos-play make up and art. She said: I know Iaposm in lockdown for  weeks, so you just have to change your mindset.
